Can Charles destroy Davout's III Corps and the Bavarian allies before Napoleon can bring his entire army to bear?

Scenario for Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Eylau
description:
February 7th and 8th, 1807 - Napoleon attacks Bennigsen's Russian army across frozen rivers during intermittent blizzards.

This brutal battle features variable winter weather rules.

Scenario for Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Sword and Dagger!
description: Medieval skirmish wargame rules for individually based figures. Each figure is classed for weapon, shield, armour, mount (if applicable), and social class(!). Combat and some movement is adjudicated by ordinary six-sided dice.
categories: Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Friedland
description:
June 14th, 1807 - Napoleon engages a Russian army attempting to a river crossing.

A scenario for the Napoleonic rules Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Raab
description:
June 14th, 1809 - Following the disastrous attempt to cross the Danube at Aspern and Essling in May, Napoleon sent Prince Eugene to confront Archduke John’s army, the only Austrian force still operating on the right bank.

Eugene finally confronted John’s army at Raab on June 14th, 1809.

Scenario for Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Salamanca
description:
Wellington's small army, having moved into Spain to threaten Madrid, finds itself being out-marched as Marmont races to cut his supply line.
As the French army maneuvers, it stretches out and Wellington sees his opportunity. Wellington, the master of the defensive battle, shows the French that he can attack!

A Scenario for Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Battle of the Pyramids
description:
July 21st, 1798 - Napoleon faces the Mameluke forces of Egypt on the banks of the Nile River.

Scenario for Commit the Garde!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Ligny
description:
June 16th, 1815 - Napoleon's last victory!

Can he beat the Prussians badly enough to force Blucher to abandon Wellington at Waterloo?

This scenario for Commit the Garde! features a battlefield predominated by villages and towns.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Quatre-Bras
description:
The third add-on scenario for Commit the Garde! covering Napoleon's last campaign.

Can Wellington's polyglot army hold the vital crossroads and maintain communications with Blucher's army at Ligny?

Commit the Garde! is a grand-tactical game of the napoleonic wars intended for use with miniature figures on a hex based battlefield.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Leutzen 1813
description:
May 2nd, 1813 - Can Napoleon reverse the fortunes of 1812 and defeat the newly united Russian and Prussian armies?

The French army has been hastily scraped together and of questionable quality, but the allied armies are also in poor condition.
It is likely to be an ebbing and flowing battle across an open battlefield around the four central villages of Kaja, Rahna, Klein Gorschen, and Gross Gorschen.

A scenario for the Napoleonic grand tactical rules Commit the Garde!

The scenario is intended for 4-6 players with brigade sized units, and should easily play in 6-8 hours for experienced players.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Aspern Essling
description:
Scenario for Commit the Garde! (Finally a scenario for the Austrians)

Napoleon, flush with a string of victories and the capture of Vienna, attempts to force a hasty crossing of the Danube to bring the forces of Archduke Charles to battle.

Will he win another decisive victory over the Austrians, or suffer defeat ?

Aspern Essling includes new rules for multi-day battles, allowing steadfast armies to continue an undecided battle.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Borodino
description:
A Scenario for Commit the Garde!

An epic struggle in the cool air of September 1812.

Napoleon's multi-national Imperial Army faces a determined Russian army before the gates of Moscow.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Talavera
description:
A Scenario for the Napoleonic rules Commit the Garde!

Can the upstart "Sepoy General" Wellesley defeat the cream of the French Army and support the Spanish forces resisting Napoleon?

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Commit the Garde: Wagram
description:
Scenario for Commit the Garde!

After the defeat at Aspern and Essling, Napoleon has consolidated his army's position, driven Archduke Charles from the field at Raab (or at least his step-son Eugene took care of that), and most of all he has meticulously planned the crossing of the Danube.
He now finds himself on the Marchfeld, where they hold their major military maneuvers.
He plans to litterally beat them decisively on their home field.

Wagram offers multiple battle options, the main sector in a double-sized battlefield (4' x 12' on 4" hex mats), either western or eastern sector sub-battles of the main sector, the Danube sector, or the entire battle spread across three normal sized battle maps.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Napoleon and the Armies of Mars: Rules for Napoleonic Battles on Mars
description:
Napoleon and the Armies of Mars is the complete set of rules for fighting epic battles between giant war-machines and expert skirmishing infantry on the battle-scared plains of the Red Planet.

Check out the other booklets in this series, get building and designing your vehicles and unleash them on your opponents!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Fantasy, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Pike & Shot & Zombies
description:
In a world already used to plagues, pestilence, famine and war, things have just got a whole lot worse. Now even the dead won't lie still in their graves. The corpses from a hundred battlefields have risen up and are now intent of devouring the last few remaining flickers of life in this truly accursed land.

Pike & Shot & Zombies is a post-apocalyptic survival game in a ravaged Renaissance world where small bands of survivors battle the hordes of the undead in a desperate bid to prolong their miserable lives for a few moments more. Each player will control one or two survivors and must withstand the fiendish scenario created by the umpire. The rules include a detailed profile of each survivor character explaining their attributes and skills. A fearsome array of armaments are available - the finest of black-powder technology - not to mention the best of the stabbing, hacking, impaling, smashing, crushing and slicing - close combat weapons available to the Renaissance soldier. But the survivors will need to be prepared, a terrifying array of undead creatures are arrayed against them. The rules describe a variety of different undead threats, from slow, stupid and frankly rather confused zombies, to faster moving more predatory undead creatures and even grossly fat zombies that can explode infections zombie goo all over an unlucky survivor.

To make matters worse for the survivors, the umpire has at their disposal an extensive deck of "event-cards". These create a wide variety of unforeseen, awkward and even downright dangerous situations that can trip up the most prepared band of survivors - from fumbling weapon handling and misfires, accidental powder explosions, to bad omens and even accusations of witchcraft. And to start players off, there are two starter missions included and guidelines for creating your own testing and terrifying scenarios using the Pike & Shot & Zombies rules.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Book, Horror, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Renaissance, Wargame, Zombies

name: Chronicles of Blood: Heroes of the Battlefield
description:
Heroes of the Battlefield is a premium expansion for the Chronicles of Blood solo war game. It adds options to include mighty champions, arcane wizards and banner bearers to your regiments in order to enhance them upon the battlefield.

You may choose any number of these Heroes as an upgrade to a regiment, increasing the points cost of the regiment in the process. However, for each one you choose, you must also choose one for the enemy army as well.

When added to a regiment, the regiment gains all the benefits that the Hero provides. Regiments can have more than one Hero added to them, and the regiment gains all of the benefits.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Quik Frik: Rules for Fast-Action Skirmish Combat in Miniatures Wargaming
description:
Got a scenario you're dying to try out, but don't want to learn pages of complicated rules?

New to gaming and ready to get your feet wet?

Experienced gamer looking for simple rules with a unique approach?

QUIK FRIK is a one-page rule set (with a bonus page) that offers a unique approach to miniatures skirmish gaming, for scenarios from WWII through sci-fi. These rules emphasize the friction that can mount during combat. They are well suited for small-scale combat, from a handful of figures up to a platoon. They are best for 6-20mm miniatures.

Rules are included for movement and combat, including vehicles. Combat results can be seen with just one roll of the dice on one combat table. A unique activation sequence is also featured. Forces can be regular or elite, and the bonus page offers many special abilities.

With QUIK FRIK, your favorite scenario can be as mindblowing as your favorite movie scene, and it can go almost as fast. So get your game on right now.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II

name: Sail and Steam Navies: Module 3 – Denmark & Prussia/Germany
description:
Sail and Steam Navies allows you to fight naval battles from the era of early steam power, iron armor, and heavy guns. In this module you have ships from the Danish and Prussian/German navies that were commissioned before 1880 and includes:

122 Vessel Log Sheets
154 1/1200 Scale Vessel Counters


Ownership of Sail and Steam Navies is required to fully enjoy this module.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Sail and Steam Navies: Module 2 – Austria & Italy
description:
Sail and Steam Navies allows you to fight naval battles from the era of early steam power, iron armor, and heavy guns. In this module you have ships from the Austrian and Italian navies that were commissioned before 1880 and includes:

156 Vessel Log Sheets
124 1/1200 Scale Vessel Counters


Ownership of Sail and Steam Navies is required to fully enjoy this module.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Modern Naval Conflicts: European Expansion Vol I – France & Germany
description:
EUROPE HAS ARRIVED!

This is the first volume of the two-part Euro Expansion for our Modern Naval Conflicts game. This expansion adds the ships, subs, aircraft, helicopters, and SAM systems for France and the Federal Republic of Germany for both the 1970s and 1980s time frame.

Players can now include the forces of France and West Germany in their MNC scenarios or campaigns: all the major surface ships, submarines, combat aircraft, and land-based SAM systems of both nations are included, along with scenarios to help get you started with the action!

This expansion features over 70 complete Unit Data Sheets, including units such as the French carrier Clemenceau, the FRG Class 143A Gepard PTG, the deadly Tornado attack aircraft, and the quiet FRG Type 206A submarine class.
Also included is a brief overview/introduction/notes on both nations forces.

Four scenarios are also included that demonstrate typical situations each nation’s forces may have faced in the European/GIUK theatre.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame

name: Modern Naval Conflicts: European Expansion – Denmark & Italy
description:
This is the first half of the second volume of the Euro Expansion for our Modern Naval Conflicts game. This expansion adds the ships, subs, aircraft, helicopters, and SAM systems for Denmark and Italy for both the 1970s and 1980s time frame.

Players can now include the forces of Denmark and Italy in their MNC scenarios or campaigns: all the major surface ships, submarines, combat aircraft, and land-based SAM / AA systems of both nations are included,!

This expansion features 50 new Unit Data Sheets.
Use of this expansion requires both Modern Naval Conflicts: 1970s and Modern Naval Conflicts: GIUK 1980s Expansion / Falklands Conflict.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame

name: Naval Warfare WW1: Expansion Pack #1 – Tsushima
description:
Naval Warfare WW1: Tsushima Expansion is a exciting addition to your NW:WW1 game. This expansion allows you to play virtually any Russo-Japanese War naval engagment.

Ownership of the base game is required.

Features:


180+ additional unit data cards!



Over 70 new classes of dreadnoughts, pre-dreadnoughts, armored cruisers, light cruisers, destroyers, a seaplane carrier, and torpedo boats!



New classes of Russian naval warships and all the major Japanese warships for BOTH WW1 and Russo-Japanese War time frames added!



2 new combat reference charts.



3 new color maps.



12 page rule book.



10 new scenarios covering the most important naval engagements of the Russo-Japanese naval war.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Nautical, Wargame, World War I

name: Dreadnoughts At Dawn: Other Powers Expansion
description:
Dreadnoughts At Dawn: Other Powers is an expansion to the Dreadnoughts at Dawn rules. It cannot be played without the full rules as it is basically just a ship data record pack upgrade. There are no rules changes included in this expansion.

It includes new ship classes for the following countries, covering the vast majority of warships available to these powers during the 1st world war. Dreadnoughts, Pre-Dreadnoughts, Battlecruisers (if any), Armored Cruisers, Light Cruisers (all destroyers are the same in these rules) are all covered for:

France
Russia
Japan
United States of America
Austria
Italy
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Nautical, Wargame, World War I

name: Bulldogs Away!! Fast Attack Craft Rules for the Period from 1950
description:
FAST ATTACK CRAFT RULES FOR THE PERIOD FROM 1950

A SET OF QUICK REFERENCE SHEETS IS AVAILABLE THROUGH THE PUBLISHER'S WEBSITE

The rules are for the recreation of small naval engagements with Fast Attack Craft such as missile boats and smaller warships, mainly in coastal waters. The period covered runs from the late 1950’s onwards and allows for the use of aircraft and helicopters.

The new 2nd edition of the rules has been updated to incorporate our standard A&AGE initiative system, where play alternates between both sides, with the winner of initiative deciding who will move the first unit each turn.

To represent the uncertainty of modern warfare units on both sides may start the battle as unidentified “blips” or Contact Markers. Forces with inferior technology may be forced to deploy their units on table, rather than being “hidden”, while superior forces may have more “blips” than units, making it more difficult for the enemy to detect where the real units are. A Contact Marker may be detected and become a radar contact, though that must be visually identified before it can be attacked. You can only attack (or be attacked) if your unit has been placed on the table as a model.

Movement is regulated by means of a system of speed settings, which reflect the maximum and minimum speeds at which the vessel may move in the current turn. The settings may be changed at the end of the turn to plan next turn’s movement, and they may also be altered due to damage.

The Combat system allows for guns and missiles of various types, and resolution is split into a Launch Phase, typically when missiles are fired against enemy targets, and a Combat Phase, where hits by all are resolved and damage inflicted. The subtlety here is that each Phase operates separately, with the order of actions alternating between the players. In the Combat Phase, the active ship does all its direct shooting, but at the end of its actions all incoming missile attacks are resolved against it. Damage it now suffers may mean that any missiles it has launched, and which have not yet been resolved, may become ineffective.

Damage is recorded in a graded system with 5 states from intact to sunk. It is also possible for vessels to suffer Special Damage, which further degrades their ability to function. There are simple rules for operating helicopters from ships, as well as rules for anti-aircraft fire with guns and missiles.

We have updated the game set up and introduced a simple points value system for players who want a relatively balanced game. There is also now a system of determining victory or defeat, based on the level of damage each force has suffered. This system represents the effect of damage to valuable assets forcing one or even both sides to retire rather than lose ships.

There are also additional rules for unconventional craft, mine warfare and operations against coastal targets.

They are rounded off with extensive data tables for missiles, torpedoes, guns, rockets, SAM systems, Air to Air missiles, ships, helicopters and aircraft. (There are 140 sets of ship data from over 40 countries).

—description from the publisher
categories: Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Officer's Handbook: For Tactical Operations in the Second World War Using 15mm Model Tanks and Infantry
description:
These rules provide players with all they require to fight land wargames set in the Second World War involving the major nations involved. We have included France, Germany, Great Britain and the Commonwealth, Italy, Japan, Poland, the Soviet Union, and the United States of America. This decision was influenced by the availability both of models and of reliable source information to help create the game data. We wished to be able to depict the sometimes subtle differences between different national characteristics, particularly regarding Infantry organization and equipment, and differences in both weapons and vehicles.

This book contains everything the Player needs to play the game. This means the rules, and the data tables. We decided not to include extensive organization tables or scenarios. There is a wide range of material readily available which Players can use when putting their forces together.

Players should feel free to prepare their games using historical formations, for which we provide guidelines about Unit structures, or they can be completely free form with Units put together as the players wish. You should not, however, mix both styles. Historically, armies did use some fairly ad hoc formations such as German Kampfgruppen with various arms of service all mixed together in Units. It was also quite common in the Western Desert for both sides to make use of captured equipment, which would give your games an additional exotic flavour.

The basic Units in the game are Platoons of Infantry or Tanks, and Batteries of Artillery. An Armoured Unit consists typically of 3-5 model vehicles; an Infantry Unit has 2, 3 or 4 Bases of Infantry, each representing a Squad; an Artillery Battery usually has 4 Guns, though there could be fewer or more depending on historical practice. It will normally have an Observer and, if it conducts an attack affecting an area, could be Off-table.

An Infantry or Cavalry Base represents a squad or troop, based on historic organizations. Some nations have fewer squads making up a platoon, though the individual squads may have larger numbers of men, giving them a better Saving Throw. We do not make use of lower level detail, such as who is actually holding any Special Weapons such as a PIAT or Bazooka.

There are a number of important features in this set of rules.

The Game Turn does not follow a strictly IGO-UGO method, though Initiative is determined in a traditional fashion.

Each Game Turn, the Players get a variable number of Orders which can be assigned to any of their troops. The number available is dependant on the number of Units in action and the effectiveness of their Commanders.

A Game Turn is split up into a number of Phases, which alternate between Players. In each Phase a Player can Activate one of his Units and carry out one or more Orders, depending entirely on what the Player wants to do. Each Order is regarded as an Action representing 1 to 3 minutes.

When a Player decides that he has taken all the Actions he wishes to with a Unit, play transfers to his opponent, who Activates one of his Units. This means that as the game develops, each Player must choose which enemy threat to react to, and which can be ignored. When a Player has run out of Orders, he can no longer Activate any Units. His opponent continues to use his Orders, and when he has used his last Order the Game Turn ends.

This system of alternating Unit Activation means that there are fewer Game Turns, but a large number of Activations and some Units may be able to make sweeping advances across the table (with all the attached risks).

Each Order expended is deemed to Fatigue a Unit, making subsequent tasks more difficult. In some cases, Fatigue is in fact just that, physically tiring a Unit. In other cases, such as when firing Ranging Rounds for Artillery, which is not going to tire out the troops particularly, Fatigue represents the effect of time being taken to check on fall of shot, etc. Players must make a decision whether to expend a higher proportion of the available Orders on some Units, at the expense of others.

The Fog of War is also present in the form of Contact Markers. These represent the uncertainty surrounding the location of the enemy. These allow the Commanders to keep the location some of their Units uncertain.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hidden Movement, Order Counters, Simulation

name: Indie Ploy
description:
A 2-4 player party game based around taking crowdfunding campaigns, represented by the blue "Pitch" cards, and creating a chain of events resulting in the campaign's failure by taking turns placing "Ploy" cards.

At the beginning of a round, a Pitch card is drawn to represent that round's campaign. Each player will then take turns playing Ploys that tie in not only with the initial Pitch, but every Ploy currently in play. This cycle will continue as long as players have cards they can contribute.

Unlike games like Cards Against Humanity and Joking Hazard, the winner of a round is determined by the total amount of cards they played. The winner will then take the Pitch card for their "Hall of Shame". The first player to get 5 Pitches in their Hall of Shame wins.

Each card in the game is based around campaigns that were pitched on crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter and Indiegogo.

—description from the designer
categories: Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management

name: Hidden Territories: Every Hero Needs a Quest
description:
Hidden Territories is a game of heroic adventure, where mighty — or cunning— heroes explore the kingdom of Westri, the nexus of the multiverse and filled with perilous monsters, nefarious enemies, and fantastical locations. Players choose one of a multitude of adventurers; their characters traverse the land encountering members of the various factions who vie for power or terrible beasts hungry for flesh — or souls. The kingdom of Westri and its inhabitants are fighting unseen forces, struggling against the grip of chaotic, entropic forces which threaten to rip apart the very fabric of the multiverse.

Play solitaire or cooperative in this game of exploration, adventure, and heroism. Consult the huge volume of the gazetteer to utilize the pre-programmed paragraph system. It’s easy to learn to play, as the programmed event sequence lets you focus on the fun of exploration as your character sets out on a quest. For each event or encounter, you, as one of the included hero player chapters, must make the decisions which will make your quest successful — or may cost you dearly. Hidden Territories has elements of a complex game designed to recapture the high adventure and heroic struggles of fantasy literature — and that famous fantasy role-playing game from the 1970s.

Hidden Territories can be largely played solo, cooperatively, or even with a but of conflict between the players. But victory can only be claimed by uncovering the true nemesis of the kingdom, and defeating a final adversary. It is a race to level up and acquire powerful weapons, armor, artifacts — even and allies. Game play sessions extend and continue, with linked quests. Time passes, and events are influenced by player choice. Heroes must use strength at arms, guile, or negotiation to defeat a hidden and ancient evil before a magical darkness envelopes all that is good.

Hidden Territories combines many different elements:

Exploration: player characters travel across the hexagonal game board to reach exciting destinations.
Random encounters: players draw encounter cards each time they enter a new hex.
Parlay, fight, or flee? many events result in opponents to negotiate with or to fight.
Random events: players draw event cards each time they enter a new tile
Leveling up: players improve their characters’ skills and knowledge of magic and gain equipment.
Paragraph Reading: an extensive plot is uncovered by reading paragraphs out of a book, discovering secrets only denizens of the kingdom know, or piecing together parts of the conspiracy puzzle. Clues help with solving mysteries and help determine how to win.


Hidden Territories features a series of Event and Encounter card decks that set pace of the game and ensures players acquiring experience to level up before they are ready to take on more difficult challenges (events and enemies). Characters acquire new spells and skills as they level up from experience. Finding loot increases wealth, so more equipment, arms and armor, and other items can be acquired. Of course, travel is perilous in this wilderness hexcrawl, so provisions, foraging, and weather all impact the heroes’ progress — getting lost in the trackless wastelands can be as dangerous as stumbling about in the darkness of some ruined dungeon.

Inside the box, Hidden Territories contains:

The large map game board, showing cities, villages, castles, and ruins scattered across 500 hexes means hours of game play exploration.
A huge Gazetteer that details the points of interest and other information about the hexes.
Standup figures representing archetypal warriors, knights, wizards, priests, and other fantastical characters.
Various decks of cards for events, encounters, items, spells, skills, and the denizens characters encounter. An analog artificial intelligence ensures outcomes are never fully predictable, and the storyline changes based on player choices.
Dice - lots of dice. Power up actions based on the dice pool, or sacrifice health or luck when heroic deeds are called for.
Numerous counters and chits to mark the location of encounters, hoards of loot, and other unknown obstacles to overcome. Use some of these to track weather, time, fatigue, and the ultimate countdown to doom.


As scenarios play out and quests are completed, players learn lore, hear rumors, acquire knowledge, train to develop martial or magical powers. Talk, trade, or fight through bizarre encounters to unravel the dark secrets behind the impending chaos.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Fantasy
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Role Playing, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Fantasy Crusaders Chess
description:
Take chess to a whole new level when even the Queen must make a 2d6 roll to see if she can capture that pawn!
Or advance the game even further with piece replacements such as elf archers, dwarven hammerers or zombie pawns all with special abilities and powers that can bring ranged attacks to the chess board and even powers to raise captured pieces as zombies in the undead horde.

This isn't your regular chess game and the battle is just beginning!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: F.o.E: Fury of Elyzium – Fantasy Tabletop Miniatures Game
description:
Cry, Havoc! And let slip your imagination.

F.o.E: Fury of Elyzium uses a version of the publisher's Fury! rules as seen in Pandora's Fury.

Designed to let you play anything from a skirmish level game up to a mass battle the rules are designed for use with any scale miniatures you wish. In keeping with the flexible nature of the system, you can use miniatures by any manufacturer in your fantasy wargames using these d10 based rules.

Whether you want to have a few brave heroes defending a village from brutal bandits, A band of stealthy Cat-man assassins raiding a Ratman camp or a Goblin horde throwing itself against the mighty citadel walls of a magnificent city, FoE is an ideal rule set for you.

Stage battles in your favourite fantasy lands from literature, TV or your own imagination or use the Elizium setting provided - it's up to you.

With rules for a wide range of creatures from animals to Wyrm kind, Beast-men to demons, FoE lets you build the army you want to field.

Customize your own magical items for your armies and characters to wield.

Clever use of manoeuvres, formations and tactics can swing a game of FoE giving the weaker (on paper) force a fighting chance if its player uses them to best effect.

—description from the publisher
categories: Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Pandora's Fury!: Post Apocalyptic Table Top Skirmish Rules
description:
Pandora's fury is a tabletop miniatures game designed to let you play out skirmishes and battles in a Post Apocalyptic landscape.

Set in the same world as "Pandora's Wake" RPG, the game lets you fight skirmishes and battles with any miniatures and in any scale.

After the 'Pandora Event' an alien world known to us as 'The Other-Verse' has ripped holes in the skin of our reality, holes through which deadly diseases, carnivorous plants and killer monsters have swept across Earth and destroyed mankind's civilizations.

In 'Pandora's Fury' you can play gangs of survivors battling for resources or simply fighting to survive or you can play swarms of creatures from 'The Other Verse' as they sweep across the landscape, destroying all they encounter.

Includes rules to convert your 'Pandora's Wake' RPG characters to the Pandora's Fury miniatures rules.

The world is ending.
Not in a single, catastrophic moment, but slowly and painfully, screaming out its dying agonies in prolonged death-throes that may last a generation. It is dying, murdered by another world, a malevolent world, a world that devours all it touches and makes it like itself, a world the survivors of our world have dubbed “The OtherVerse”.

In Pandora's Fury the players will create groups of survivors who are struggling to stay alive in a post apocalyptic world that is being over run by the incursion of the Other-Verse and its hostile flora and fauna, which are slowly and inexorably turning our world into a copy of their own. Survivors must battle these hostile elements of an alien world, gather supplies and deal with other bands of survivors, some hostile, and some not, to try and survive in a world gone mad.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Blackwood Chainsaw Massacre: Scenario for Pandora's Fury!
description:
In the early years of the fall of human civilisation, several back woodsmen have survived due in no small part to their isolation from larger pockets of habitation. The Alien diseases which ravaged the cities after “The Pandora Event” ripped a whole in the fabric of our reality, letting the Other-Verse in, have yet to trouble the small community.

The residents of Blackwood would like to keep it that way.

The small community has already begun to fortify itself with barbed wire and by constructing other fortifications, including a watch tower. Now they have also begun to clear the woods closest to their micro community in order to create a field of fire and to remove cover form any one or any thing that may try and approach the small community and may seek to do it harm.

While out felling trees, however, some of the locals discover that there are already creatures from the Other-Verse lurking in their woods, and they are hungry!

“The Blackwood Chainsaw Massacre” is a skirmish scenario designed for the “Pandora's Fury!” rules but which can be easily modified for any other skirmish rules you like. Statistics for the combatants are included, using the Pandora's Fury! rules system. Use any scale or miniatures you like.

The Scenario pits lumber jacks and townsfolk against the horrors of the Other-Verse in a desperate fight for survival.

This scenario was featured in the games room at Moria Con 2015.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Linnoituksen Kingi
description:
Linnoituksen Kingi is a roll and move game that pits players in a race aound the city of Hamina. Players see local places and meet local people all the while trying to be the first ones to cross the finish line.

The game is made by the city of Hamina.

—user summary

"Lähde seikkailulle Haminan ympyröihin ja voita linnoituksen herruus!

Kuka peruuttaa sinua päin haminalaisella luontopolulla? Miten Haminassa googletetaan? Mikä mahtaa olla suosituin välipala kauppatorilla? Mitä tarkoittaa, kun jonnee mennää tuurilla?

Näihin ja moneen muuhun kysymykseen löydät vastauksen tästä pelistä! Lähde seikkailulle ympyräkaupunki Haminan linnoitus-keskustaan ja sen ulkopuolelle, kohtaa jännittäviä tyyppejä ja voita itsellesi Linnoituksen valtiaan titteli!"

—description from the back of the box
categories: Educational, Humor, Travel

name: Ingogo 1881
description:
Ingogo 1881 is a Ascari Scenario and it has to be played with Ascari rules.

During the First Boer War, General Colley, commandant of the British troops in Southern Africa, decided to clear his lines of communications from Mount Prospect camp to Newcastle from the Boer threat. He collected a mixed force of 5 companies of the 3/60 Rifles, some artillery and the Mounted Squadron formed by men from 58 Rifle. Arrived at the plateau of Ingogo, known also as Schuinshoogte, he met the Boers who started to fire with precision, pinning the whole column.
The precise aim of the Boers neutralized the guns first and pinned the British on the plateau; to reduce pressure, Colley ordered the Mounted Squadron to attack, but the Boer fire blocked the attempt. As well, the charge of Captain MacGregor with a company failed as well.
A fierce thunderstorm broke down and the situation for the British worsened as they suffered fatigue and exhaustion; as evening fell, Colley realized that his men would be able to stand there and ordered a retreat; the Boers did not guard the British convicted that they were in no position to move from the heights and thus the British managed to escape.

Will you manage to pass the plateau or will you defeat the Empire with your burghers?

40 gorgeous counters, a colorful A4 map and English rules wait for you!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Kassala & Tucruf
description:
Kassala & Tucruf is a game with two Scenarios for Adowa, game on the battle in Africa from Acies Edizioni.

You need to have the game in order to play the Scenarios.

KASSALA 16th July 1894
The Italian Governor Gen. Baratieri organizes the conquest of Kassala, Dervishes stronghold in Sudan. After a quick advance and a fierce combat, the city is conquered by the Italians.

TUCRUF 3rd April 1896
The Italian garrison of Kassala, led by Major Stevani, attacks the Dervishes camp at Tucruf but after a fierce combat must return to its base.

A colorful map, two play aide, two Specific Rules, more than 40 gorgeous units.... you just need to have Adowa!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Modderfontein 1901
description:
Modderfontein 1901 is an Ascari Scenario and it has to be played with Ascari rules.

During the Second Boer War, the Commandos tactics in guerrilla managed to continue the war, even if the capital cities of the Boer Republic had fallen.
Commandos led by intrepid and young leaders started to harass the British lines of reinforcements and the Empire responded with flying Corps with Mounted Cavalry and the internment of the Boers non combatants into concentration camps.
The Boers decided then to raid directly Cape Colony, where several Boers lived and partake for the Republics; Jan Christian Smuts led the most daring raid.
In the attempt to cross Elands River, the short for ammunition and supplies Boers decide to attack the 17th Lancers camp near Modderfontein, managing to surrender the Lancers and loot the camp... the bitter end is still far away!

Will you manage to loot the camp and replenish your supplies or will you be defeated by the Empire?

27 gorgeous counters, a colorful A4 map and English rules wait for you!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame

name: The man who would be king
description:
The man who would be king is the new Ascari Scenario based on the novel of Rudyard Kipling.

It is a two players or also a solitaire game!

This battle is portrayed in the John Huston movie of 1975; Dravot, Carnehan and Billy Fish lead the Bashkai tribe against the Er Heb tribe for their very first battle in Kafiristan.
The British style fusiliers will win the day, with the assistance of the Dravot miracle; despite being hit by an arrow, he is saved by its bandoliers and the Er Heb recognize him as heir of Iskander, Alexander the Great!

It is necessary to have the Ascari set of rules to play the game;
a nice map, 20 colorful units and two pages of rules are waiting for you!

Would YOU become a king?

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Jutland: Naval Wargame Rules for the Dreadnought Era 1906-1918
description:
NAVAL WARGAMES RULES FOR THE DREADNOUGHT ERA, 1906-1918

These rules are quick and simple to play, providing a fast game of naval action in the era of the Dreadnought between 1906 and 1918. In the scale we use, 10cm represents 1 nautical mile to 10cm. The rules incorporate weather, spotting, submarines, aircraft, shore batteries and minefields. They take account of Crew Quality and allow for the use of Contact Markers to represent the initial uncertainty of exactly where the enemy forces might be.

The gunnery system is simple and you roll 1d10 to hit with each gun. When you score a hit, an innovative damage system takes account of the gun calibre and range to determine which type of dice is used to test for penetration and the amount of damage inflicted. Torpedo and Mine attacks use a similar mechanism, so there is a consistent feel throughout the combat system. Not all guns can engage all vessels, and the largest guns have a minimum range. Simple aircraft rules allow for air attacks against ships and for air to air combat.

In line with the intention of the rules to provide a simple system, armour is standardised for each type of vessel, and guns are grouped by calibre into 10 classes. Detailed differentiation between the performance of specific guns and ships is not present.

A collection of ship data is provided covering significant vessels from 10 nations in this period, with over 300 vessels. A simple conversion system allows you to create game data for ships not in the lists provided.

The rules also include the Order of Battle and pre-prepared data sheets for all the ships that took part in the Battle of Jutland.

Recommended scale: 1/1200 TO 1/6000
Complexity: 5/10
Level of detail: 4/10

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War I

name: Angels 15: Aircraft Data Supplement for Scramble!
description:
This data encyclopaedia for Scramble provides over 500 additional aircraft for your Scramble dogfights.

Information is provided about 5 theatres of operation for World War Two, as well as for minor wars of the 1920’s and 1930’s.
This enables you to pit appropriate aircraft against each other for the area and date.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Polskie Państwo Podziemne
description:
Polskie Państwo Podziemne is a historical, educational boardgame about the Polish Underground State during WW2.

Each player will have his own set of tiles, representing different members of the Polish Underground State. The objective of the game will be to associate those characters to the different pillars of the underground structures.

There are four variants in the game including one, which consists in creating a set of connections between the characters represented in the game.

The booklet inside the game box includes also a detailed, historical description of all the characters.

It was designed by employees of the Institute of National Remembrance.

—description (translated)

Polskie Państwo Podziemne to edukacyjna gra historyczna, przybliżająca specyfikę i kadry polskich struktur podziemnych w trakcie II wojny światowej.

Każdy z graczy dysponować będzie zestawem płytek, przedstawiających postacie Polskiego Państwa Podziemnego i jego zadaniem będzie przyporządkowanie tych płytek do odpowiednich obszarów działalności.

W grze dostępne są cztery warianty rozgrywki, w tym jeden, pozwalający na tworzenie sieci powiązań pomiędzy postaciami.

W instrukcji znajduje się także obszerny materiał, przybliżający każdą z występujących w grze postaci.

Gra została zaprojektowana przez pracowników Instytutu Pamięci Narodowej.
categories: Educational, Memory, Spies/Secret Agents, World War II

name: Stations Manned and Ready (2nd Edition): Rules Support Package
description:
STATIONS MANNED AND READY II IS A SET OF NAVAL WARGAMES RULES FOR THE PERIOD 1885 TO 1945 USING SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT

This file is a set of PDF files in a Zipped Folder, and is for use as support material when playing SMR II, which is required to make use of these files.

The Documents is the Zip folder are:

Game Template Booklet
Ship Data Description Booklet (two files)
Maritime Aircraft Data Booklet
Ship Data catalogue
Ship Data "Glossary" Booklet (two files)
Merchant Vessel Booklet


In addition, the following "Taster Battles" are included. These allow you to start playing the game and include the ship data sheets for the battle in question. The datasheets included in these files all incorporate the updated ship data and are laid out in the new format.


Pre-Dreadnought:
Battle of Santiago
Battle of Port Arthur




WW1
Battle of Coronel
Battle of the Falkland Islands




WW2
Battle of the River Plate
Battle of Denmark Strait
Battle of Cape Bon
Battle of Tassafaronga
Battle of Kolombangara



—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame, World War I, World War II

name: 1944: Combat Shock
description:
With the introduction of CPOP's Retrowave Collection, 1944: Combat Shock has been remastered, restored and resurrected. Return to the fields of battle. Return to the hell of World War II.

You can now enjoy the game originally published in 2013, with minor changes, including updates and grammatical alterations. 1944: Combat Shock returns in an updated revision.

In Combat Shock, players construct either platoons or full companies and engage in brutally quick and easy to play skirmishes across the battlefields of World War II. Miniatures in 15mm scale are mounted on bases to represent teams and scenarios determine the kind of battles fought. Players can play small-scale skirmishes on tabletops of 2 by 2 feet, to epic-scale conflicts on 4 by 4 foot tabletops.

This digital rulebook is in PDF format and includes basic and advanced rules, as well as several playable scenarios, rules for platoon and company construction, force lists for Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, the United States of America and Great Britain. Also included are rules for battle conditions and more.

—description from the publisher
categories: Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Zombie Game
description:
Zombie Game is a action board game utilizing 3d Miniatures. Players can choose, draft, or be given random Characters to take on Missions. It is a Tactical level action game. The Zombies themselves are moved by the Zombie Turn Token holder. Each turn this is usually a different player and also the player that goes first that turn. The game uses normal 6 sided dice and with an easy to play rule set. Characters must sneak, fight, and Search for items to survive. It can be played solo, as a co-op party system, or a vs party system.

—description from the publisher
categories: Dice, Fighting, Horror, Zombies
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Turn Order: Random

name: Toxic Holocaust
description:
GRAXX is home to a wasteland unlike any you have encountered before, from the mutants roaming the highways to the survivors trying with all their might to cling on to any sense of hope, it is here where damnation reigns supreme.

Toxic Holocaust is a tabletop miniatures game of brutally quick and easy skirmish battles between rival gangs on a post-apocalyptic world, where survival is nothing but a dream, as the reality of living, dying and thrashing is the only truth and one that will kick you in the teeth very, very quickly. Are you ready?

Revisit the original 2009 first edition of Toxic Holocaust, fully restored and remastered. The rules allow you to create gangs and the members of your gangs entirely from scratch, including weapons, traits, abilities, mutations and much more. Add the ability to field vehicles and customize them, and you're in for one hell of an apocalypse.

Join us, as the original Toxic Holocaust miniatures game returns, from CPOP.

We welcome you to the Goremageddon. May you live, die and thrash.

Goremageddon is heavily inspired by over-the-top violence, exploitation, gore, horror, humor and post apocalyptic films on the 1980s, as well as RetroWave and Thrash Metal music. Goremageddon is also CPOP's flagship project, made popular by a cult following.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: An Overdose of Death!
description:
In 2012, CPOP founder Neuicon unleashed his vision of a post-apocalyptic world called GRAXX, set in an alternate reality to ours, where the fantasy world of GROMM once flourished. The game would later become CPOP's flagship title and see a rise in popularity due to its many, many insane influences: thrash metal, synthwave, over-the-top violence, gore, horror, exploitation, action, fantasy and the post-apocalypse, all of which would be mashed up into a bad 80's Italian film and spew forth, the Toxic Holocaust, also known as the Goremageddon. Add to it, the ability to create gangs and every member of your gang from scratch, including their traits, weapons, equipment, abilities, spells, mutations, vehicles, the ability to see action on the very first turn and much, much more, and you have in your hands a game of maximum overdrive.

An Overdose of Death! allows you to create a gang and every member in that gang from scratch (purchasing the unit's base rank, traits, abilities, equipment, weapons, mental or physical mutations, spells and more), play in three different modes (standard, boss and grudge), fight on battlefields in 2 by 2 to 4 by 4 feet in size, play a variety of scenarios and through several different battlefield conditions, field vehicles and totally customize your vehicles from scratch and much, much more.

We welcome you to revisit the original second edition, originally released in 2012, along with everything ever released for the game, such as: Toxic Holocaust 2: An Overdose of Death! (introducing six factions: the Wasteland Warriors, Unholy Crux, Skravers, Reptors, Thermonuclear Warriors and Omega Corporation), Waste in Space: the Fatal Feast! (introducing two new factions: the Doom Legion and Prophets of Mars), Saalythic: Rise of Deraathis (introducing the Saalythic faction) and Black Inferno: the Raiders of Atlantis (introducing the Raiders of Atlantis faction).

Included with your purchase is a 1920 by 1080 HD wallpaper of An Overdose of Death!, so that you may adorn your screen with the madness of the Goremageddon.

We welcome you to the Goremageddon. May you live, die and thrash.

Goremageddon is heavily inspired by over-the-top violence, exploitation, gore, horror, humor and post apocalyptic films on the 1980s, as well as RetroWave and Thrash Metal music. Goremageddon is also CPOP's flagship project, made popular by a cult following and already headed into a third edition, due to release soon.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Horror, Mature / Adult, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Pizzatown
description:
Pizzatown is a town that loves their pizza! As an owner of a pizza restaurant, you will create and deliver pizzas… but be careful, Pizzatown is also home to Pizza-hungry Monsters who want to eat your pizzas! Deliver the pizzas, avoid the monsters, upgrade your ride and earn the most money to win the game!

In Pizzatown, the game has four phases: Take a pizza order; Buy ingredients to make the pizza; Deliver the pizza; and Earn profit from a successful delivery. However, as the delivery person heads towards their destination, the pizza monsters who live in the sewers might smell the pizza passing by and come out to chase the pizza! If they catch your delivery person, they will eat your pizza and your profits!

Players can use profits to buy more ingredients from a market that changes every turn. Or buy vehicles and upgrades to make faster deliveries. Improve your restaurant buy purchasing an additional oven. Spend your money wisely however, because the player with the most money at the end of the game, wins!

—description from the designer
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Economic
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Market, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Castle Dice: The King
description:
Originally made by Jay and Jordan as a birthday present for Luke Peterschmidt. Only 100 copies ever exist.

Card states:
Play at any time.
Set this entire game aside and play a different game of your choice. You may return to this game at any time
categories: City Building, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval

name: Remoundo τυφλόμυγα (Blind man's bluff)
description:
The original version of the game was played in Ancient Greece. One individual is blind-folded in order to catch or touch one of the others who run around.

Remoundo games, the publisher of this game, brought this traditional game on the table with the title "τυφλόμυγα" which means "blind fly".

There are two different ways to play, depending on the double-sided board.
Side A (blue) : One player, designated as "It", is blindfolded and the other players choose a pawn. Everybody's places their pawns on the board and they try to avoid the "it" from catching their pawn. If "it" catches a pawn , he/she places it randomly on the board. The board indicates some sounds (animal sounds, human sounds etc) and the person who had this pawn must immitate this sound. "It" has to recognise him/her . If so, the person who recognised gets a penalty card and becomes the new "it".

Side B (green) : The "it" chases the other people by rolling dice. There are also 27 character cards (with 3 dinstict elements each)and everyone takes a secret caracter card trying not to reveal their character as they run to escape from "it". If the "it" catch a player, he/she can ask them 2 more questions and if he/she find their secret character they take a penalty card and they become the new "it".

When a player reaches the 6 penalty cards, everybody checks their own penalty and the person with the fewest cards is the winner of the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Party Game
mechanics: Hidden Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: InFARMation
description:
Your dad is a pretty amazing guy. He came out west during the gold rush and was one of the few that actually got rich! Now, he's nearing the end of his life and want's to choose the successor to the plantation he built.

Dad isn't what anybody would call "normal" in any respect. So, when he decided to choose his successor using a contest of his own design, nobody was shocked.

The rules are simple and the prize is becoming the head of the family. As the head of the family it will fall to you to ensure the plantation stays running and everyone stays fed.

Dad wants you each to mimic what he did to become the man he is. So, you'll start with nothing but the clothes on your back and you'll have to gather resources to use/trade/sell in order to "build" each of the main plantation assets. Obviously these already exist, so you'll be paying dad a number of resources that he has estimated to be the value of each asset. Once you've "built" an asset, you can work it or assign your workers to work it and gain the resources and points for that asset.

---
1. Hunt, Gather & Fish for Food
1. Clean animals for Leather
1. Mine Stone for building
1. Mine Gold ore for trading
1. Use the Sawmill to make timber for building
1. Use the pigsty for food AND leather
1. Use the smelter to turn your ore into pure gold
1. Hire workers and assign them to work your assets
1. Bribe away workers from your siblings to gain an edge

---

Dad says, if you want to win**






You will have to work hard
You will be smart
You will be sneaky and shrewd
You will use all of the inFARMation at hand to build your strategy and create the best plantation in the time allotted.


——description from the designer
categories: American West, Farming
mechanics: Bribery, Dice Rolling, Income, Push Your Luck, Worker Placement

name: Cartoon Car Crash Course Part 1: The Rules
description:
Cartoon Car Crash Course (C4) is an excuse for adults to play with some of the amazing toy cartoon vehicles available at toy & department stores, garage sales, flea markets, & inside “children’s” fast food meals (thank goodness for drive throughs!). We provide rules for six kinds of cartoon vehicles: Conventional, Wacky, Spooky, Futuristic, Superhero, & Supervillain. You choose a vehicle type & a theme that fits your vehicle. Next you pay points to purchase Add-Ons (cartoon weapons, special abilities, hazards, tricks, & so on) that fit your theme. A wide variety of possibilities are included so you can create (or recreate) almost any cartoon vehicle; the points system keeps them balanced.

From 2 to 6 players race their toy cartoon cars using a simple simultaneous movement system; attacks are also simultaneous. Collisions & attacks are resolved quickly. If a car loses all of its damage points, it Blows Up, loses some Cheers (which you collect to be able to win the race), moves back 2d6”, then keeps on going. All of this means lots of action & very little down time for players.

C4 plays quickly & is suitable for both younger players & older players with short attention spans (like most gaming groups, in our experience). It plays faster than most other car combat games & can get pretty hilarious at times.

With 6 vehicle types, 6 cartoon themes, 15 customizable weapon types & more than 40 customizable add-ons to choose from, you’ll be able to create or recreate just about any ‘toon vehicle imaginable – as long as you have a toy vehicle that can represent it. The points system keeps them balanced, so a Wacky baby bird in a jalopy or a beagle sitting on a doghouse with imaginary machine guns can cause just as much mayhem as a Superhero in a specially designed ubermobile.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Racing, Sports

name: Line Up
description:
The aim of the game is to get an orthogonal line of 5 pieces of your color in a row. The grid size is 8 x 8.
It is an old game (from a series that also includes Cross Over and Target) that has been out of stock for decades.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: Target
description:
The aim of the game is to get as many rows of at least 3 pieces of your color as possible, either along the outlines of the circles or along the radia.
It is an old game (from a series that also includes Cross Over and Line Up) that has been out of stock for decades.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: For King or Country
description:
For King or Country is a cooperative based game in which players work together as Members of Parliament to enact a velvet revolution in their country, peacefully overthrowing the monarchy and establishing a fully fledged democracy. Like in any government, corruption and self interest make getting things done nearly impossible. It’s up to the player to navigate the political landscape keeping the people, the military, the monarch, and others happy while they pursue their goals. By passing and amending legislation, players can change the very makeup of the game, making it easier or more difficult to meet their ultimate end goal.

The main venue of participation players can make it through using MP Cards. MP Cards come in three varieties: Actions, Amendments, and Events. Actions can be played at any time to win over MPs from across the aisle, help more of your party members get elected, and even filibuster a bill you don’t want to pass. Amendments on the other hand are attached to a bill in question, only going into effect if it is passed by Parliament. Amendments could change the effects of a bill, alter the rules of the game, and even dish out some pork barrel spending to your constituents. The final type of MP Cards are Event, disastrous circumstances that affect whichever player has drawn the card. These Events can be from a crisis in your district, to an embarrassing scandal that ruins your reputation.

—description from the publisher
categories: Political

name: Grace Flynn: Tides of Forever
description:
Grace Flynn - Tides of Forever is a tabletop miniatures game where players try to help Grace and her stalwart crew survive in the hostile underground world of the Shadow Sea. The rules for the game are based on the game system for ShadowSea - Conquest of the Underground World, using dice and tactical choices to complete different battle scenarios.

The game is designed for solo play, with rules for the environment, wild creatures, enemies and special game effects. Multiple players may take part if they wish, running the enemies or playing one of the four main personality characters from the Grace Flynn stories of Phil Lee McCall. The main character is Grace Flynn herself, the notorious pirate with her sword Tyrfrost and magical Bloodsilk sash.
This book contains a complete rule set showing how models (the miniatures or markers for each character or enemy) move, fight and do actions in the game, such as searching for artifacts or swimming through shark-infested waters. There is also a small section on the flora and fauna of the Underlands, the subterranean region of a hollow Earth where Grace and her crew must escape.

The core rules in this book are based upon the Song of Blades and Heroes (SOBH) game engine by Ganesha Games and are designed for fast and furious play with plenty of heroic action, ethereal magic and advanced technology, all handled with a few rolls of 6-sided dice. The rules have been designed for battle using 28 mm “heroic scale” miniatures, with one figure representing one character or creature.

Game scenarios are played on a tabletop and require an area of 24 by 24 or 36 by 36 inches with scenic materials for terrain such as water, ruins, trees, and other obstacles added. Each scenario in the book has a map layout that shows where players and enemies start and where scenery can be placed.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Spacemaster 2120
description:
Space, 2120. FLT was discovered decades ago, along with a surprising number of inhabited worlds. Now, in regions throughout the galaxy, the search is on for mineral-rich asteroids. In Spacemaster 2120 your small mining craft will explore the 24 sectors of SR-227 and collect six types of minerals. Planets in the sector have different demands for these minerals, so to turn a profit you must plan your movements carefully and act accordingly. You’ll also have to convince the inhabitants to trade with you – or use force to convince them. Fuel is no longer an issue, but you’ll have to visit Earth for the turbo variety or convert some Uraninite. Other minerals can be used for various purposes, although it's usually better to deliver them for profit… and don’t forget to watch out for those darn pirates!

Spacemaster 2120 can be played on instinct, casually or seriously. Players can deduce what minerals (and to a lesser degree, planets) have yet to appear. They can look ahead one or more moves -- "if I do this he will probably do that." It's up to the players. You can play aggressively or peacefully. The rules set is small, there is exploration, meaningful choices, screwage, a bit of combat and some luck. A typical sequence of turns for a player might be: explore, mine, move, try to trade. Lots of "flow," fun and replayability to be enjoyed in this light and fascinating space game.
categories: Print & Play, Space Exploration
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Tile Placement

name: Isles of Treasure
description:
In Isles of Treasure players take the role of ship captains exploring the surrounding sea looking for treasure while avoiding marauding pirates and sea monsters. The board is made up of tiles placed face down at random during setup. All players begin at a shared stronghold. Players gather supplies until they feel ready to venture out to sea. Each time your ship moves it costs supplies, so the further out you venture the more expensive it is. You also use supplies to flip tiles face up discovering what is hidden underneath. What you find could be something good like an island to resupply on or search for buried treasure, or it might be pirates who ambush you and take everything in your cargo hold. Don’t worry you can get revenge on those scurvy pirates, just resupply, sail out after them, and take back your treasure by force. The only way to ensure your treasure is safe is to get it back to the stronghold. Once there, it scores victory points for you. Until you get it back, other players can attack your ship and take it for themselves. The game is over once all of the tiles have been flipped face up. Whichever player has the most treasure safely secured at the stronghold wins.

—description from the publisher
categories: Exploration, Nautical
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Take That

name: War Chess: Diplomacy of the Three Kingdoms
description:
The Three Kingdoms period of China was a time when great characters rose to lead factions with the kingdoms of the day and eventually unite China under one dynasty through a series of military and diplomatic campaigns featuring temporary alliances, civil war and conquest. You are now one of those characters!

—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Negotiation, Political, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Gridlock
description:
Gridlock is a pattern building game for 2 to 4 players.
All the action takes place on a 7x7 square wooden board.

Every turn you have to choose a wooden 2x2 square tile and place it on the board. These squares consist of randomly areas in the colors red, yellow, green and black.

Whenever you place a tile, you check whether you have created a larger area of any color and count the points.

Tiles may only be placed directly on the board or stacked if the top tile lies on at least 2 different tiles without falling off.

The game ends if there are no tiles left or no places to build anymore. The player with the most points wins.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: Four To Score
description:
Four To Score is a dynamic word search game played on a 4x4 grid. Players stack letters to make and score four-letter words in any direction. As letters are stacked and unstacked, new words game be continually formed.

The Lasercut game consists of a six-inch game board and 100 single-letter tiles.

Players strategically stack and unstack tiles, scoring any four-letter words found until someone exceeds a predetermined target score.

Can be played solitaire.

—description from the publisher
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Word Game
mechanics: Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game, Tile Placement

name: Olde English Chivalry Game
description:
A game played on a board of 9 × 9 squares, for up to four adults or children.

Each player selects a gaming character (Jester, Poet, Prince, Knight) and places the appropriate standee piece on the applicable starting square located at the corners of the board (Jester's Court, Poet's Corner, Prince's Palace, Knight's Castle). A neutral Princess playing piece is placed on the Castle square in the centre of the board.

There are a number of plastic chips representing gold and silver coins (seemingly three of each) which are placed in a provided draw bag labelled "Olde English Swag Bag".

Players then take turns in drawing a coin out of the bag, and moving their piece accordingly. Coins are of two types - silver and gold - and the player must move his piece to a square of the same kind that is adjacent to the one he is on (orthogonally - no diagonal moves are allowed). If a legal move is available, it must be made, even if the player feels it is disadvantageous; if no legal move is available, the player does not move his piece. The coin is then returned to the bag, and play passes to the next player.

The object of the game is to rescue the trapped princess from the castle, and to be the first to carry her away to safety.

As well as the four corner squares, Princess's central castle, and gold and silver coin squares, other spaces are marked with taverns, witches, fighters in various poses, a dragon (occupying 5 squares), fallen log (2 squares), broken bridge (2 squares), and ?river gorge (3 squares). The purpose of these squares is unknown. Also unknown is why the game appears to be equipped with a total of nine character pieces, some of which appear to be duplicates.

Also known as Gaymer's Old English Chivalry Game - the manufacturers of Gaymer's Olde English Cyder also promoted a Compendium of "Inne Games" at about the same time, comprising dominoes, a cribbage board, two packs of cards, and poker dice.

—user summary
categories: Medieval

name: Squadron Strike!: Ship Book 1
description:
Ship Book 1 for Squadron Strike features class histories, specifications, fully-rendered illustrations, and Ship Data Sheets for 15 ships from the Human Diaspora setting.

If you're a fan of naval architecture, and gorgeous art of spaceships, this is the book for you!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Squadron Strike!: Material Condition Deck
description:
This is an expansion of the table that appears on page 125 on the Squadron Strike rulebook, done as a custom deck of cards.

What these cards do is add complications to ships in space combat games, color coded by type.
They can also be used for setting up initial conditions for RPG adventures, say with Star Trek Adventures.

Some scenarios in Squadron Strike will tell you to draw cards from the deck before the scenario starts to show the impact of ships being on the tail end of long patrols, and they functionally act like random terrain in making scenarios more interesting.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Role Playing, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Ocean
description:
This game consists of a box with holes in the lid, 15 sticks and 12 magnets. The bottom of the box is a metal plate.

The game can be played in four ways.


Fishing:


One player places the magnets. The other player tries to hit the magnets with the sticks.


Treasure hunt:


One player places the magnets in four lines of three. The other player tries to hit the magnets with the sticks.


The boat game:


One player places the magnets as they wish, but with at least one empty spot between eacn. The other player tries to get across the board without hitting the magnets with the sticks.


Stepping stones:


One player places the magnets forming a path. The other player tries to get across the board missing the magnets as little as possible. For a harder game, also place a false path.

—user summary
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game

name: Kaiju Attack
description:
A cooperative tower defense game in which players attempt to prevent the Kaiju from destroying the last standing cities.

The game includes 180 cards, including Kaiju, Generals, Cities, and Resources.

Each turn, players will draw resource cards, build and deploy weapons, and attack the Kaiju. Players are encouraged to play cooperatively, trading resources (especially when they begin to become scarce), planning strategies, and combining attacks to deal the most damage to the Kaiju each round.

The Kaiju will then take a turn, destroying the city and stomping the weapons the players have built. Each Kaiju has a special ability that makes them harder to kill. As they crush the cities underfoot, resources become harder to get, making it more difficult to build and deploy weapons).

The game is won when all the Kaiju are dead and there are still cities left standing. The game is lost if the Kaiju destroy all remaining cities.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Horror

name: Streaks & Ladders
description:
Do you like fun, games, and public nudity? Well then, get ready for this race n' chase game where nudity wins! You and three other players run around the Tri-Piques Waterpark With one goal, experience every attraction the park has to offer and escape, all while streaking and avoiding capture by the lifeguard.

Players take turns rolling and moving about the board in a non-linear fashion. The goal is to reach each of the ten locations on the board. Some spots on the board require one to draw a 'Flasher' card which can cause the player to move locations, miss a turn, escape from jail, ect. Once they have done so they may mark it off of the scorecard. Once all ten locations have been visited, the player must escape the park via one of it's two exits. One player plays as the lifeguard. His objective is to chase down each player. Once he has reached a player, both are moved to the jail. The lifeguard then continues on to try and catch the others. Players can be let out of jail by others if they can reach the jailhouse location on the board. The game ends when either everyone has escaped or everyone is captured. The winners are those who escaped or the lifeguard if anyone remained captured at the end.

—description from the publisher
categories: Humor, Mature / Adult

name: Skateland
description:
Do you have what it takes to dominate on skates? You and up to three of your friends will go head to head to see who is the most x-treme aggressive inline skater of them all.

Move about the board (a run-down skate park) finding places to pull off tricks. Once you've found a spot, play a trick card and note its point value. If you can, play a trick multiplier, like a grab or a spin, to add to your base trick points. Then roll to multiply those points. Watch out! If your trick is too complicated, there's a risk you might take damage. Too much damage and you're out. Your opponent gaining too much of a lead? Play a trap card to sabotage them. First player to 10,000 points wins!

—description from the designer
categories: Sports

name: Dirt Track Saturday Night: The Starting Field Expansion
description:
This is the product that makes Dirt Track Saturday Night even more fun to play, plus much more convenient and economical to own.
The counter set is designed to fit the full size track as well as the medium and small versions of the track.
This makes DTSN the most accessible and enjoyable racing game on the market.
This product does require that you have the full set of rules for Dirt Track Saturday Night.

The full color car counters are based on actual race cars from the 1960's and onward. The rut markers change the racing surface so that each racer must choose his line with greater care. The variable number and location of the ruts means that each race will be unique in its own right. Whether you play a single race, one night's worth of races or a season of races, the decisions you make will matter even more. The best part is that the rut rules are an extended application of the existing rules; not a change.

Dirt Track Saturday Night is very playable, yet challenging. The Starting Field Expansion just adds more of that "it just feels right" character that all gamers desire.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Racing

name: Moments of Sheer Terror: Core Rules. Mid 20th Century – Mid 21st Century
description:
Warfare has been described as protracted boredom punctuated by moments of sheer terror.

The core rules of Moments of Sheer Terror are focused on the individual infantry of the mid 20th century to the mid 21st century. Blaster weapons as well as conventional slug throwers are the stock in trade of the infantry in this time period. Fixed wing and rotary wing aircraft are included. Futuristic vehicles such as grav boards that hover 6 to 12 inches above the ground are available as well for individual troopers.

Moments of Sheer Terror is a skirmish level game that operates on an initiative based system for the troops to take action. When you take certain actions, such as firing a weapon, there is a chance that one of 64 random events will occur. Some events will help you, other events will help your opponent.

The rules are written to avoid vertical exaggeration by having the figure scale match the ground scale. Buildings, trees and other features are meant to be played as they are modeled.
There are charts included for 6mm, 10mm, 15mm, 20mm, 25mm and 28mm figures.

One turn equals 30 seconds.
The combination of the ground scale and turn length means that air support is handled with elegant simplicity. (In 6mm scale a soldier figure moves 6 inches in one turn. A ground attack aircraft would move 88 feet.) Just choose the altitude; high or low. Then put the aircraft where you want it on the table.

The charts are where the detail is in the game. This means the core rules can be used for different eras with slight modification for that era.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Quick Intermediate Level Skirmish
description:
Quick Intermediate Level Skirmish or QILS is a simple and quick skirmish level wargaming system.

It supports multiple genres of gaming, based on supplements.

Out of the box (well, the .pdf) it is ready to play with a few suggested sides and scenarios.

The current genre supplement is for a fantasy world (which has a lot of nice material, ready to transfer over to another system), with upcoming releases for scifi and pulp adventure!

—description from the publisher
categories: Fantasy, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame

name: SINS: Mark of Lust – Battle Pack
description:
SINS is a fantasy card deck-builder with a quick setup and gameplay, filled with a plethora of combos and tough choices throughout the game, in a small package.

To win, gain power, give despair and resolve your dominance.

Components
70 x SINS cards.
20 x Kosmos (starter) cards.
2 x Dominance cards.
5 x rules cards.
3 x misc. cards.

Setup
Each box supports 2 players. Use multiple boxes when playing with more than 2 players.

Deal 10 Kosmos (starter) cards to each player. This is their draw pile, placed in their play area.

Give each player a Dominance card and place it with the Cortadoo logo facing up.

Shuffle all Sins cards together face-down, from the box sets of your choice. Place the cards in the center of the table to form the Realm.

Each player draws a card from the top of the Realm. The highest card-number is the active player (repeat if there is a tie). Destroy these cards. Destroyed cards are placed back in the box.

Then, draw 5 cards from the top of the Realm, into the center of the table, face-up.

All players draw 5 starting cards into their hand from their draw pile (this is their hand limit).

The active player starts the game and takes their first turn.
How to win
When a player reaches two dominance, that player wins the game and the game ends immediately.

You get dominance by resolving opposing despair in the Status phase, and you give despair by attacking your opponents in the Attack phase.

The Dominance card in front of each player has numbers from zero to three. If you’d like to play a longer game, you can optionally play until a player reaches three dominance. For a short (coffee break) game, play for one dominance.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy
mechanics: Action/Event, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Take That

name: SINS: Era of Sloth – Battle Pack
description:
SINS is a fantasy card deck-builder with a quick setup and gameplay, filled with a plethora of combos and tough choices throughout the game, in a small package.

To win, gain power, give despair and resolve your dominance.

Components
70 x SINS cards.
20 x Kosmos (starter) cards.
