Quotations from the Epic of Gilgamesh (Babylonian, 2nd Millennium BC)

You’ve seen the Rules now its time for the Armies!

Featuring:

58 detailed Army Lists for armies of the Ancient World between c3500 and c1500 BC, from Europe, the Middle East, the cradle of civilization in Egypt and Mesopotamia to India and China.
Short military histories of the main ethnic and/or regional groupings covered by the Army Lists.
Explanatory maps and illustrative time-line diagrams to provide additional clarity and insight.
Full explanation of how to employ the Army Lists to produce miniature armies of our period for use with Warlord Rules and other wargames rules systems.
Commentaries on the composition, organisation and troop types in each Army List
Brief explanation and discussion of the weaponry and equipment of the time – including bows, swords, spears, battle carts, chariots, bucklers and shields.
The potential allies of each army are listed, and where appropriate, their particular enemies are identified.
The landscape categories typical of the home territories and/or imperial possessions of each historical army are specified, and full explanations of each landscape category are given.
Guidelines indicating the potential quality of command within each army are provided.
Additions to Warlord Rules are explained and discussed.
Cross referenced internally and with the Warlord Rules, throughout.


The DAWN OF WAR is the first in a series of Army List books covering the development of fighting forces from the Earliest Times to the Enlightenment, enabling the construction of miniature armies for Ancient, Dark Ages, Medieval, Renaissance, Pike & Shot and 18th Century Warfare.

—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: The New Zealand Wars: War in the East 1866 (Hawkes Bay)
description:
This book carries on the New Zealand Wars conflict with background provided about the history and people that took part in the war.

The War in the East focuses on the actions that took place in the Hawkes Bay Province that was looking at an attack on the Napier Town in September to October 1866.

Donald McLean the Hawkes Bay Superintendent, deemed that an attack from Hauhau forces under Pai Marie war priest Panapa, order commander of the Military district force Lt-Colonel George Whitmore to assemble the milita and volunteers to meet this threat.

The booklet is full of information and details about the actions and battles that took place. Information you will find inside are the orders of battle, descriptions, and important dates of the campaign. To play the scenarios and compaign you will need the rules which are in a previous title - The New Zealand Wars - Skirmish & Campaign Rules; The Waikato War

Scenarios :

Raid the Armoury, 24th September 1866
Battle of Omarunui, 12th October 1866
Battle of Petane, 12th October 1866
Pursue the Fugitives, 15th October 1866


This bring to life a little known conflict that took place on the east coast of New Zealand in the Hawkes Bay Province during the New Zealand Wars.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Bingo Hall Brawl
description:
Bingo Hall Brawl is a fast-paced two player dice game of luck, tactics, and spandex. Go head-to-head with your opponent - simultaneously rolling ten dice to decide who wins each lock-up, gets to execute offence, and win over the rabid pro wrestling crowd.

Using a mixture of attacks, counter-attacks and blocks, your aim is to build your posture enough to hit a finisher and pin your opponent for a count of three! Crowd reaction tokens can be earned and used to unlock steel chairs, start ‘this is awe-some’ chants, or lower your opponent’s posture to give you some space to recover. The dice decide the outcome of each grapple, but it’s up to you to decide when to play to the fans and when to fight dirty.

Once your posture reaches a certain point you can attempt a pin: both players break out their pin dice and roll them once for each count from the referee. If you can score equal to or higher than your opponent three times in a row the bell rings and you are declared the winner! If not they kick out and you lock up again. It’s unpredictable, it’s tense – it’s pro wrestling!

—description from the designer
categories: Dice

name: Coronavirus Card Game
description:
THE WORLD IS FIGHTING A PANDEMIC.
BUT YOU NEED FOOD AND TOILET PAPER TO STAY AT HOME.
This fun game is about fighting a pandemic and stereotypes people see these times.

You play as usual citizens and have to survive. You need to stay at home, but if you don't have resources you need to go outside risking to get a virus.
- Accumulate food and toilet paper
- Hide if you are ill
- Steal food

To start, all players take a character card and a corresponding lucky card. All player cards are face up.

Rounds: Every round is a new day. Each turn, you can choose to go outside or stay at home, use food, and toilet paper, or take cards.

If decided to go outside, you can take a minimum of 1 and a maximum of 2 cards

How to prevent the disease:
Use your mask before you start drawing cards. Then if you draw a virus, you will not get ill. Use sanitizer if you get a virus (it kills the virus). Use your lucky card (always helps) as a last resort.

How to manage the disease:
If you are infected you have 2 options:

Reveal (change state to not hiding the virus) then you have to call a doctor (use DOCTOR CARD) 3 turns in a row.

Hide – act as a usual citizen but an Inspection card reveals your disease, so you have to reveal being ill and start treatment. After that, the virus is discarded.

ANY player can reveal that another one is ill (only if that player has a virus). The revealed player has to start treatment.

IMPORTANT
VIRUS + VIRUS = DEATH
LOSE EVEN IF YOU ARE IN TREATMENT
IF A PLAYER DIES – THE VIRUS RETURNS TO THE DECK

How to win:
When the deck ends and no live players have a virus – they all win.
When the deck ends and at least 1 player has a virus – they try to survive till the end of resources.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play

name: Matchlock: ECW Rules for 1/300th Scale
description:
Matchlock

Rules for miniature wargames in the English Civil War using 1/300th scale figures.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Debrecen: Battle of the Hungarian Plain, 1944
description:
Debrecen (possibly spelled Debrecan on early copies) is a game about the Soviet offensive into Hungary in October 1944.

The game uses daily turns and a scale of two miles per hex. Units are battalions and companies. Double-impulse movement is used.

In addition to the 16-page rulebook the game includes over 300 hand-mounted counters and four photocopied map sections which combine to form a 20"x23" map.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: I Corp
description:
I Corp [sic] covers the North Vietnamese campaign to take the northern part of South Vietnam in March 1975.

The map is 16 by 28 hexes and covers the area from Dong Ha to Quang Tri.

Combat is voluntary. Movement is constrained by a large number of special rules. There are other special rules for artillery, fuel supply, naval support, and civilian dislocation.

An alternate scenario has the South Vietnamese 1st Parachutist Division not being withdrawn to Saigon.
categories: Vietnam War, Wargame

name: II Corp
description:
II Corp [sic] covers the North Vietnamese offensive in the Central Highlands in March 1975.

The map is 16 by 28 hexes and covers an area rougjly from Nha Trang to Bong Son. It has some color, unlikely many Perry Moore productions of this period. There are 11 two-day turns.

All units are battalions except for a few ARVN Regional Force companies. The ARVN are hampered by morale rules and supply rules. There are special rules for a possible intervention by B-52s and for Thieu's withdrawal order.
categories: Vietnam War, Wargame

name: Apocalypse
description:
Apocalypse covers the final battle for Saigon from April 1st-May 12th 1975.

The map is made from five small sheets of different sizes which join to form a roughly 37 by 41-hex area from Tay Ninh to Bung Tau. The NVA units are regiments except for tank battalions; all ARVN units are battalions.
categories: Vietnam War, Wargame

name: Rules for Wargames: 18th Century Warfare
description:
18th Century Warfare

Miniature wargame rules for conflicts in the 18th century using miniatures between 6mm and 25mm in scale.
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Germany's Tank Attack: 1918
description:
This game takes place during the Second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux in late April 1918. This was notable for being the first tank-vs.-tank battle ever fought.

The game map covers the central portion of this operation at a scale of 180 yards per hex. Units are infantry platoons and individual tanks. Turns are 90 minutes.

A contemporary reviewer noted some issues with the game, e.g. the fact that there is only one night turn after the 12 day turns so it is impossible to reproduce the actual events (in which Australian troops counterattacked at night).
categories: Wargame, World War I

name: Triumphant Standards: Political Warfare Between the Wars for Through The Mud and The Blood
description:
Triumphant Standards supplement covering the 1938 Very British Civil War, the Irish War of Independence and the Freikorps in the German Civil War!

Free expansion available per request after purchase of Through The Mud and The Blood
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War I

name: Fighter Command
description:
Fighter Command is a detailed game clearly about the Battle of Britain, although the map depicts an imaginary island nation being attacked by an imaginary continental nation.

The rules cover speed, altitude, fuel, radar, sighting, differences among airfields, reconnaissance missions, and much more. The level of detail allows players to experiment with different tactical choices, e.g. the "Big Wing."

Turns are 10 minutes each and must be plotted well in advance.

In addition to the rules and the 11"x16" map the game includes 132 uncut counters.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II

name: Papeon Paper Wargame
description:
Papeon is a papercraft based tabletop wargame. The game mechanics rely mainly on the actual physical ability of the paper figure itself. That means, if a player wants to attack an enemy unit from a distance, a player must craft a paper figure that can do exactly just that!

Essentially each player takes turns controlling several paper figures of various types and battles them against another player’s paper figures.

With Papeon, players will have a great time not only while playing but also when crafting and customizing the paper figures.

Craft, Customise, and Charge!

—description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Miniatures, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Mój pierwszy Alias
description:
A word game with popular Disney characters. Develops vocabulary in preschool children. Big, nice and solidly made cards with heroes from favorite cartoons. Passwords are items or characters known to every child.
Everyone is playing at the same time - you don't have to wait for your turn.
The game is intended for 3-6 players aged 3+.
Contents: Board, 192 cards, 8 pawns + plastic stands, rotating arrow with stand and hourglass.

The game is about guessing the passwords on the cards. The player takes a card from the face-down pile and turns the hourglass that measures the time. Then explains the card word descriptively. If the correct answer is given before the hourglass sand spills over, then both the explanatory player and the teak who guessed the password move their pieces on the board. The first player at the finish wins the game.

—user summary
categories: Children's Game

name: Ambush: Epic
description:
“A brave warriors group enters the shadowy dungeon, with the intent to defeat the cruel evil forces inhabiting there. Dungeon darkness, battle stress and gloomy fluids emanating from its walls will push our courageous heroes to their limits. The battle is not only against the evil forces, but also against each other, to obtain the greatest glory and the biggest loot.”

Ambush: Epic is a semi-cooperative board game for 1 to 4 players. Lead your hero to the creepy and darkest nook of the dungeon. Balance your competitive and cooperative skills, get stronger but don't forget to give a hand when it is needed. Don't let the evil forces win! Reap the glory by yourself or share it with your allies.

Be part of the epic crew, making the villagers write ballads about your feats. May the best strategy reap the glory!
categories: Adventure, Dice

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Basic Campaign Rules
description:
The book contains an introduction into 18th Century Warfare including both land campaigns and naval campaigns. The land campaigns include information on troop types, weapons, formations and battlefield tactics. The Naval includes information on the ships armament, naval strategies and fighting tactics.

The unique system of Decision Games is explained, which with the use of Programmed Events and Chance Events form the basis of the campaign rules which are included.

In the campaign modules the commanders are given historical objectives and the forces that were available to them. This book provides the rules to re-fight the campaign modules with the methods for troop manoeuvres being dependent upon their commander’s ability, weather and plain luck. Forces march along defined routes, must maintain a line of supply and set down depots. They suffer from sickness and desertions but occasionally receive reinforcements. The rules also include a system of bidding which accurately portrays the skirmishing and manoeuvring prior to a battle or withdrawal.

Troop strengths are always recorded in terms of Army Points (APs) or Naval Points (NPs). This book gives an in depth justification of the balance between APs NPs and VPs (Victory points) based on extensive research. The system greatly simplifies campaign logistics.


Strategic Map Manoeuvre.
Commanders’ Personalities.
Programmed Events.
Rules for Off table encounters for pre-battle scouting and rearguard actions.
Rules for post battle pursuits and rearguard actions.
Points system for evaluating Campaign Results.
A unique system for determining battles by dice rolls.
A unique system for determining dice rolls by telephone.


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Fortress & Siege Rules
description:
The siege rules make use of the authors Decision Games system which enables a siege to be conducted in terms of Stages as outlined by the great French military engineer Sebastion de Vauban. The system uniquely and realistically enables the timing of the advancing stages of a siege to run sequentially with the land campaign and along the timetables set by Vauban and so make sense in the context of a campaign.

Within the campaign system, each fortress is classified as being either weak, medium, strong etc. and a Victory Points value (VPs) incorporated into the initial balance. Dependent upon the strength of the fortress it is allocated a garrison strength (APs) and a garrison morale value (GM) plus a proportionate amount of provisions (GPRs).

Similarly the besieger whose strength (APs) is dependent upon the situation in the campaign, monitors his own force’s morale (BM) which will vary as the siege progresses and with comparison with Vauban’s timetable. The presence and size of any siege train or the approach of a relieving force are also critical to success.

This siege system enables the besieger to choose from a variety of tactics which may vary at each stage. These include sapping, bombardment and stratagems.
The defender similarly has a number of tactics to hand including stratagems and even the occasional sortie which can lead to a table top encounter.
The progress of the siege is dependent upon a cross reference of each side’s tactical choices some of which result in either a Reaction Test by the Garrison or the Besieger. These can result in surrender, a lifting of the siege or a continuation.


Siege Decision Game Mechanics.
Garrison’s Morale (GM) and Besieger’s Morale (GM).
Garrison’s Provisions (GPs).
Log’s for Sieges of Fortresses including Reaction Tests.
Truth Tables.
Diagram of a typical Vauban fortress and the siege stages.
Honours of War (HOW).
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Rules for Land Battles
description:
The Land rules contain comprehensive standing orders for each troop type and battle orders assigned to each commander. Dependent upon the circumstances encountered during a game these force players and units to act historically. The casualty system uses HIT dice which translate immediately into battlefield and campaign casualties. After battle pursuits and rear guard actions necessary for a campaign are also included.

Units are organised as battlefield brigades rather than battalions or regiments to reflect the actual practice of the period and to fit in with the campaign system. This avoids the predicament which arises when army numbers are reduced by casualties and desertions and yet the number of battalions and regiments remains constant.

Commanders have an ability rating to reflect their own personality and that of the ability of their staff. Initiative each bound is dependent upon the ability of the commanders and dice rolls. Movement is alternative and dependent upon initiative. Charge Tests, Reaction Tests, shooting and melee is simultaneous.


Formations.
Organisation.
Troops Points Values (APs).
Order and Command.
Reaction tests.
Pre-Battle Manoeuvring.
Table Top Terrain Maps.


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Rules for Naval Battles
description:
This book contains the Table Top Rules for Naval Battles.

The rules are suitable for both fleet actions and also small one on one encounters.

It includes an introduction to 18th century naval actions and tactics.

The battles are fought on hexagons with fleets manoeuvred with a system using specially designed order cards which players are invited to photocopy for their own use. Speed and manoeuvrability being dependent upon size of the ship, wind direction and the number of sails in use.

Damage is inflicted with the use of HIT dice. The HIT dice and associated Tactical Factors reflect range, size of gun and the size and protection of the enemy target ship. These are recorded by crossing out boxes on the ships log.

The ships are divided into Ships Of the Line (SOL) and Repeater ships consisting of Frigates, Sloops and Brigs. The Ships of the Line are further categorized by the number of guns that they contained. 90 gun, 80 gun, 74 gun and 64 gun. The simple game mechanism includes alternative moves in which orders are secretly chosen in advance and apply to the whole fleet and reflect the difficulty of handling multiple ships simultaneously as was the responsibility of 18th Century Admirals.

The simplicity of the rules enables fleet actions of ten or more ships per side to be completed in a single two to three hour wargaming evening with the pre action manoeuvring being a vital and enjoyable feature.


Order Cards – Ships of the Line.
Order Cards – Repeater Ships.
Order Cards – Ships of the Convoy.
Table Top Battle Logs for Fleet Actions.
Table Top Battle Logs for Small Actions.
Rules Synopsis.
Players Reference Sheet.


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Introductory Campaign – Mollwitz
description:
This campaign is set in Silesia part of modern day Poland in the winter of 1741 and at the beginning of the second year of the conflict popularly known as the First Silesian War which later expanded into the wider conflict known as the War of the Austrian Succession. It attempts to re-enact the attempt by the Austrian army commanded by Marshal Niepperg to march to the relief of the blockaded fortresses of Neisse and Brieg and to simultaneously cut the Prussian occupying army’s lines of supply. Had the Austrians succeeded, King Frederick II (The Great) of Prussia would in all probability have been forced to surrender because his position in Silesia would have been untenable.

Frederick was taken by surprise and with many of his troops being dispersed into winter cantonments, it was a race against time to concentrate his forces before being attacked by the Austrians. Early on at the battle of Mollwitz it went badly for Frederick who fled the field only to discover that his army had gained a victory during his absence.

The campaign module does not aim to slavishly recreate the attempted relief of Silesia to the last historical detail. Nor does it attempt to fight the whole war or even every engagement across central Europe during 1741. Finally of course, it does not aim to re-fight the battle of Mollwitz on replicated terrain and with the historically accredited troops there. Instead it provides players with the information and mechanics to re-fight the Mollwitz campaign closely based on historically accurate forces, commanders and strategic considerations.

Its aim is to provide an interesting (and challenging) backdrop or context for table top battles.

This was a very short campaign being all over in less than 2 weeks. There are no sieges, naval actions or reinforcements involved. Consequently, it serves as an excellent introduction to the campaign system.

Contains:

Historical Background.
Campaign Map.
Commanders.
Initial Army Strengths and Fortresses.
Progremmed Events.
Chance Events.
Army Lists.


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: Land Campaigns I – Nish, Cuneo & Zondorf
description:
This Book contains 3 standalone land campaign modules.

The Nish Campaign, 1737. Austrians v Ottoman Turks.
This campaign is set in Serbia in the late summer of 1737 during the Austro-Russian-Turkish War of 1736-39. It attempts to re-create the invasion of Ottoman Serbia by a Habsburg Imperial army led by Marshal Count Friedrich von Seckendorf and its opposition by the Ottoman Grand Vizier Al Haji Mohammed who commanded the Ottoman Army on behalf of his master the Sultan.

The campaign ended in a disastrous failure for the Austrians following their defeats at the battle of Valjevo and the recapture of Nish by the Ottomans.

The campaign includes at least one siege against a medium fortress (Nish), the probability of two other sieges and unusually the probability of some fortresses being besieged, captured and then re-besieged and recaptured by the relieving forces.

Special features of this campaign include the fact that the invading army decimated by sickness and in particular malaria, eventually becomes the prey. They are pursued and virtually destroyed by an aggressive relief force led by the Grand Vizier and defeated at the battle of Valjevo.

It also pits a poorly trained and equipped European army against a basically irregular Asian army with a high proportion of cavalry.

The Cuneo Campaign, 1744. French and Spanish v Austrians and Sardinians.
This campaign is set in north-western Italy in the summer of 1744 and is part of the wider conflict popularly known as the War of the Austrian Succession 1741-45. It attempts to re-create the Franco-Spanish (sometimes referred to as ‘Gallispan’) invasion of Piedmont, led by Prince Louis de’Conti which was opposed by Charles Emmanuel the King of Sardinia (Piedmont) with an Austro-Sardinian army who fought to protect his kingdom. Although victorious at the battle of Madonna dell’Olmo, the campaign ended with the Gallispans being forced to withdraw from Piedmont after torrential rain destroyed their siege works at Cuneo.

The campaign includes a potential siege or storming of a Weak Fortress, and a number of potential sieges against Weak and Medium Fortresses including the historical objectives of Demonte and Cuneo.

The Gallispan lines of supply across the Alps is an important and special feature of this campaign. The French objective was to capture an important fortress to be used as a base for the campaign planned for the following year. Another feature is the fortifications known as the Barricades built by Charles Emanuel to prevent the passage of enemy troops through the Stura Valley. The maneuvering and audacity of the Gallispan attack which resulted in the capturing of the fortifications was hailed as the feat of arms in Europe at the time.

The Zorndorf Campaign, 1758. Russians v Prussians.
This campaign is set on Prussia’s eastern borders with Poland in the summer of 1758 and is part of the wider conflict popularly known as the Seven Years War 1756-63.
It attempts to re-create the invasion into Prussia by a Russian army led by General Villim Fermor which was opposed by King Frederick II who personally commanded his own Prussian Army. The campaign ended after the bloody draw at Zorndorf with the Russians withdrawing from Prussia and Pomerania.

The campaign includes a potential siege or storming of a Basic Fortress, and a number of potential sieges against Weak Fortresses including the historical objective at Custrin/Kustrin (modern-day Kostrzyn).

Special features of this campaign include the fact that it has one army the Prussians, actively rushing to force a battle and destroy the enemy. A definite Napoleonic strategy and a far cry from the usual 18th C. maneuvers to capture fortresses or other possessions.

Each module contains its own:-
• Historical Background.
• An account of the historical campaign.
• Campaign Map.
• Programmed Events Table.
• Chance Events Tables.
• Army Lists.
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Line of Sight, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: 18th Century Wars of Absolutism: The Caribbean Naval Campaign
description:
The naval campaign The Caribbean uses the unique Decision Games system and is based on the campaigns of 1781 and 1782 between the French Admiral Comte Francois de Grasse and the British Admirals Sir George Rodney, Sir Samuel Hood, Sir Francis S. Drake and Thomas Graves during the American War of Independence.

It includes three naval Decision Games.

Martinique re-enacts the arrival in the Caribbean of de’Grasse with the French fleet and the attempted interception of them by Sir Samuel Hood and his British fleet.

The Windward Islands re-enacts the attempts by de’Grasse to capture either Tobago or St Lucia whilst again Sir Samuel Hood attempts to prevent this.

The Big Prize is based on a conglomeration of the 1781 and 1782 campaigns where in 1781 de’Grasse had the option to either assist the Americans or to attempt to gain further possessions from the British in the Caribbean whilst 1782 saw the engagement between Sir George Rodney and de’Grasse at The Saints off Dominica.

Each of these Decision Games will produce a naval action which may be a major fleet action or a minor skirmish scenario such as Small Convoy, Pirates or Trapped. Table Top scenario maps are supplied for all possible outcomes.

A concise but well researched history of the occupation of the Caribbean Islands is included to give a thorough strategic and diplomatic back ground and to put the American War Of Independence into perspective from the British and French point of view.


History Naval Campaigning in the Caribbean Islands
Table Top Battle Logs for Fleet Actions.
Table Top Battle Logs for Small Actions.
Campaign Log British.
Campaign Log French.
Programmed Events.
Chance Events.
Campaign Map – The Caribbean.
Three Naval Decision Games.
Table Top Scenario Maps.
Reference Sheets for Scenario Small Actions
History of Naval Battles of the 18th Century.


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame

name: Spider-Man: Goblin Grab! Card Game
description:
Villains threaten the city. Led by the notorious Green Goblin, they will surely crush all that is good and right. Spider-man has his work cut out for him-and it will take all his Spidey-speed to grab the Green Goblin(and all the cards) first!

Based on the popular game Slap Jack, this fast-paced card game will keep the Spidey-action flowing battle after battle.

52 card deck includes an instruction card and 3 BONUS VILLAIN CARDS!

How to play:

The goal is to win the Green Goblin and all the cards, by being first to slap each villain card as it is played to the center.

Deal cards one at a time face down, to each player until all the cards have been dealt. The hands do not have to come out even. Without looking at any of the cards, each player squares up their hand into a neat pile in front of them.

Beginning on the dealer’s left, each player lifts one card at a time from their pile and places it face up in the center of the table.
When the card played to the center is a villain card, the first player to slap their hand down on the villain takes it, as well as all the cards beneath it. The player winning these cards turns them face down, places them under their pile of cards, and shuffles them to form a new, larger pile.

When more than one player slaps at a villain, the one whose hand is directly on top of the jack wins the pile. If a player slaps at any card in the center that is not a villain, they must give one card, face down, to the player of that card. When a player has no more cards left, they remain in the game until the next villain is turned. The player may slap at the villain in an effort to get a new pile. If the player fails to win that next pile, they are out of the game.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game

name: Acronymity: Player's Choice Edition Expansion
description: The Player's Choice Edition expansion adds 476 new question cards to the Acronymity board game, in which you answer questions about acronyms and abbreviations. The publisher compiled this new set of questions from suggestions sent in by customers who'd bought the original game.

name: Serengeti: A Race For Life – The Ranger
description:
This is a mini-expansion of the base game of Serengeti: A Race For Life. It can be used in the standard version of the game opposing 2 players as well as the multiplayer version.

The Ranger replaces one of the Trail card in the players starting decks.

With the Ranger players now have the ability to track animals located under rocks, right from the start of the game and without relying on an animal skill. They can also place it on an animal stack of their choice to protect it, potentially securing 2 points at the end of the game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Action/Event, Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management

name: Evolutionary War: Miniature Gaming an Age in Which War Had Rules
description:
Evolutionary War offers historical miniatures battles that open with sweeping Grand Tactical Manouevers, and then shift to an innovative command and initiative system where enemy units compete against their Morale Grade to complete the Tactical Evolutions expected of them during the course of an hour, rather than against whoever rolls the higher die. There are no markers or other battlefield clutter, the basing system lets the figures do the work! Assuming the units perform like clockwork as expected, Evolutionary War offers miniatures rules for an age in which war had rules. The challenge is in planning battles that takes advantage of those rules, the rewards come in historical miniatures battles that suit an age in which “taste” governed everything.

Period: Players can span the globe from Europe to the Americas or India ; as far back in time as the First Silesian War in 1740 and up to the early battles of the French Revolution before 1794.

Scale: The principal unit of the age was the infantry or cavalry regiment—militarily and socially—so the game is organized around this scale, with regiments as the basic playing pieces. This also allows players to campaign as the Chefs of particular regiments, without the huge expenditures necessary for battalion level games!

—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Ranger Danger
description:
Ranger Danger is a cooperative, 1-4 player board game where each player takes the role of a park ranger who has become separated from the rest whilst camping in a perilous forest: to win, they must find the central path again, reunite with the rest of the team, and make their way home. However, the forest is full of all manner of monsters and beasties who emerge once the sun sets, and the team must make their escape before the night fully draws in.

Each game of Ranger Danger proceeds over two distinct phases of play:

In Phase 1 (“Build the Forest”), players place tiles on the board to map out forest paths that will bring them back together and help them find the exit; placing monsters where required. In Phase 2 (“Escape!”), players move around the board, battling enemies and trying to survive long to make their way to the ‘Home’ tile.

If all four Rangers reach the central ‘Home’ tile before the Forest Tile stack has been fully depleted, they will successfully survive the forest and win the game.

—description from the designer
categories: Exploration
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Tile Placement

name: Rich Man Poor Man
description: Mid 70's roll-and-move game where the object is to become the "Rich Man" by being the first player to move a pawn onto each of the yacht, the mansion, and the bank.
categories: Unspecified

name: Labyrinthspiel
description:
The goal of the game is to escape the labyrinth of the minotaur. Movement is determined by a die.

—user summary
categories: Mythology
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Battle for the First Panzer Army
description:
Battle for the First Panzer Army covers the breakout of the eponymous army from its position in Ukraine in the spring of 1944.

The 21"x30" map (in four sections) has a scale of three miles per hex. There are over 200 counters; most units are regiments or divisions. There are fourteen turns of one day each (there is only one scenario).

The core systems are mostly standard. The Germans get an additional mechanized movement phase after combat. Combat itself is the most unusual aspect; the strength ratio determines not a column to roll on but a table, with the column in that table determined by troop quality and terrain. Troop quality has three levels and the highest-level units exert better zones of control than others.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: The Quick & The Undead: Fast Play Zombie Rules
description:
(Based upon Jane Austen – Zombie Killer Regency zombie rules by Jasmin Storey-Smith also by Partizan Press and available from Caliver Books)

The Quick and the Undead is a game for one or more players, based upon more zombie movies, TV shows, comics and stories than is healthy for one person to know about!

Designed for fighting the Undead, but easily adaptable for Human on Human survivalist games.
Excellent for single scenario, or Campaign.
The random generation of buildings, Loot and other features makes this ideal for SOLO play.
Players are either human or Zombie… or both

Get it while you can. !!!!!!

It is the early C21st. Given the upheavals in Britain outlined in the background above, technologically, socially and musically it is about the Mid 1970’s. So too are the clothing fashions!

Cities and towns have been ransacked and then abandoned to the Undead. Survival lies in small villages in the British countryside.
Remember that this isn’t a gun-happy US TV show.

This is a Campaign driven system, players start with a bunch of unarmed starving survivors that work their way up to hardened professional survivors… but don’t get too attached to anyone!. Of course one-off games are a must too.

Games should be scenario driven (find food, grab guns from a police station, empty fuel from cars on a road…. and then get the Hell out of Dunnie on the Wold) or a straight points based Shoot‘em Up (well, Bash‘em Up).

The possibilities are endless and you’ve seen enough films, etc. to sort it out.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Wargame, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game, Turn Order: Random

name: Battalion: North Africa '40-'43
description:
Battalion: North Africa '40-'43

Battalion is a world war two rule set detailing the North Africa Campaign from 1940 to 1943.

It is 1:1 miniature to real life counterpart representation. Using 6mm scale miniatures and terrain.
Players may wish to use 3 or 10mm miniatures also but other scales are not officially supported.

The rules are detailed yet fast. Action is decisive, ranges are of engagement are long and movement distances are also relatively big.

What you see is generally what you get and the game has a lot less abstraction compared to other wargames.

The game features a quick play sheet, there are charts to look up sometimes.

—description from the publisher
categories: Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Tempus Quest: Episode 12 – We Were Here
description:
Episode 12 of the Tempus Quest series of games by Button Shy.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer
categories: Print & Play, Puzzle, Science Fiction
mechanics: Grid Movement, Network and Route Building, Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Budgies With Grudges
description:
Budgies With Grudges is an adorably twisted card game for 2-4 players.

It combines hand management with strategic gameplay, that see's players face-off in battle to become the ultimate champion of a bird-cage fighting league.

Feathers will fly and beaks will break in this brutally cute and frantically paced beat-em-up card game, from the creators at Brain Blips.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game

name: Napoleonic Scenarios 6: Imperial Sunset
description:
Volume 6 presents thirteen historical scenarios that follow Napoleon’s famous 1813 & 1814 campaigns. All are designed for use with General de Brigade Napoleonic wargames rules, (but may, of course, be converted to any similar system).
Each scenario provides players with terrain maps, troop deployments, objectives and orders of battle. Several of the scenarios are linked and can be combined to fight one large action or played as part of a mini-campaign.


Lutzen: The Prussian Charge.
Lutzen: La Garde au Feu!
Lutzen: Action at Eisdorf.
Bautzen: Franquemont’s Attack.
Dresden: Murat’s Flank.
Kulm: The First Day.
Hagelberg
Dennewitz - Ney’s Battle.
Dennewitz - The Saxon Battle.
Leipzig: The Battle for Dolitz.
Leipzig: Schonefeld.
La Rothiere.
La Rothiere - Marmont’s Flank


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Napoleonic Scenarios 7: Shadows Over the Empire
description:
Volume 7 comprises eleven battle scenarios from the 1813 campaign.
All are designed for use with any Napoleonic set of rules, though recommended for General de Brigade.
Each scenario provides players with terrain maps, troop deployments, objectives and orders of battle.
The scenarios can be played in chronological order as per the real campaign.


Kalisch: Defend the bridges
Mockern: Keep the roads open
Konigswartha: Italians under fire
Weissig: The Cohorts of French National Guard
Reichenbach: Break that line
Goldberg: Rush for the hills
Blankenfelde: Prendiamo la città (let’s take the town)
Gross-Beeren: To Berlin
Thiessen: The Crossroad
Wartemburg: Bloody terrain
