name: Word Tac Toe
description:
Two to four players (solitaire too) compete to make 3-letter words to control territory in this Lasercut word game.

Players combine a single letter A-Z with a two-letter bigram on the board to make a 3-letter word. Flip the tile over to point the arrow towards the player. Own three words in a row to score a point.

—description from the publisher
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Word Game

name: L'Aigle: Napoleonic Rules
description:
Miniature wargame rules for the Age of Napoleon and the French Revolution.

For 10-28mm figures.

Stand based. 3 figures per stand.

Scales varies from an average 300 men per stand in the smaller scales to 180 men per stand in the larger, thus giving Divisional up to Corps level games.

— description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: North Africa: Campaign in the Desert 1940-42
description:
North Africa was the first original "monster" game published in Japan. It is played on a 22"x96" map (made of two 22"x48" sections) which stretches from near El Agheila in the west to the Suez Canal in the east.

The game contains 24 counter sheets with a total of 3,168 counters. Based on a picture the counters on the map may be generic with specific units in holding boxes, but this is somewhat speculative.

The rules are relatively short. There are eleven chart and player aid sheets separate from the map. Based on the turn record on the map, the campaign game lasts for 119 turns (presumably weekly).
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: The Gallant Few
description:
The Gallant Few is a very detailed simulation of tactical air combat in the Battle of Britain. It is a simplification of the designer's earlier game covering 1944 and later.

There are several tactical scenarios and information on a campaign game.

The game contained rules, aircraft data cards, charts, and uncut counters, all packaged in a cardboard binder. Only about 30 copies were made.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II

name: Champs de Mars: Napoleon's Campaigns – 1806: The Campaign Against Prussia
description:
Champs de Mars - Napoleon's Battles is a series of modules that details the land battles of the Napoleonic and French Revolutionary Wars.
It provides the Orders of Battle and maps of the large battles as well as the smaller combats of an entire campaign, as well as the odd battle that were fought on the periphery of the main theatre.
Designed to be a source of inspiration and enjoyment for wargamers of this colourful and fascinating period.

For L'Aigle or any Napoleonic rules system.

1806 - THE CAMPAIGN AGAINST PRUSSIA

Maida - 4 July 1806
chleiz - 9 October 1806
aalfeld - 10 October 1806
Jena - 14 October 1806
Auerstadt - 14 October 1806
Greussen - 16 October 1806
Halle - 17 October 1806
Criwitz - 3 November 1806
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Champs de Mars: Napoleon's Campaigns – 1806-1807: Winter Campaign Against Russia
description:
Champs de Mars - Napoleon's Battles is a series of modules that details the land battles of the Napoleonic and French Revolutionary Wars.
It provides the Orders of Battle and maps of the large battles as well as the smaller combats of an entire campaign, as well as the odd battle that were fought on the periphery of the main theatre.
Designed to be a source of inspiration and enjoyment for wargamers of this colourful and fascinating period.

For L'Aigle or any Napoleonic rules system.

The second volume in the series Champs de Mars - Napoleon's Campaigns covers the first half of the 1806-07 campaign against Russia, Prussia's ally. Starting in December 1806 with the Battle of Czarnowo, it culminates in the Battle of Eylau deep in the harsh Polish winter.

1806-1807 WINTER CAMPAIGN AGAINST RUSSIA, lists:

Czarnowo - 23 December 1806
Kolozab - 24 December 1806
Pultusk - 26 December 1806
Golymin - 26 December 1806
Mohrungen - 25 January 1807
Bergfried - 3 February 1807
Hof - 6 February 1807
Eylau - 7 February 1807
Eylau - 8 February 1807
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: About Bonaparte: Fast Play Napoleonic War Game Rules
description:
About Bonaparte: Miniature Wargame Napoleonic rules for 25 to 54mm.

Artillery is classified by weight , having light, medium, and heavy designations. Light artillery can either be foot or horse, while all other weights are foot.
Infantry has line (standard), skirmish, and irregular troop types.
Cavalry has heavy, medium, light, lancer, and irregular troop types. Heavy cavalry can be further designated as being Armored or not.
For each of those troop types you can further classify them by morale: green or untrained, trained, veteran, and elite or guard.

Commanders are rated only by type and not by morale.
They are the CIC, Generals (commanders of corps, wings, or divisions), Officers (commanders of brigades or regiments), and Staff Officers (aides and staff of CICs and Generals).

The book gives you rules for all of the major powers, including the Ottomans.
Each nationality has special rules, including formations that their infantry can use.
Russian line fires with one less dice, British with one more, but only at point-blank range; that sort of thing.
There is a point system to cost out the troops in all of their variations.
There is no army lists, per se, and you are expected to research out who had what troop types and so on.

About Bonaparte covers more than just the Napoleonics period.
There are period rules for the Age of Marlborough, the Seven Years War, the French and Indian War, the American War of Independence, the American Civil War, and the colonial wars.
categories: American Civil War, American Revolutionary War, Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: In the Grandest Manner: Companion – 1809 Danube Campaign from the Situation Room
description:
This publication is part of a planned series of Companions to both support and supplement the rules, In The Grandest Manner, with themed scenarios that are developed and played at “The Situation Room”.

To make use of this Companion, you do not require any specific set of rules, although they are written with the rules mentioned above in mind.

Indeed, the Companion lends itself to being scaled in virtually any way the reader wishes, for use with a plethora of rule sets.

In addition to the scenarios, time is spent on exploring the intricacies of the rules which the Companions supports. In this edition, the focus is on the game setup, focusing on the work going into setting up any game. After set up, the morale system is examined in depth, exploring the troop definitions that can enable as much variation as wanted or indeed warranted by any scenario.

The scenarios, themselves, are based on four main battles from the Danube Campaign of 1809 between the French, commanded by Napoleon, and the Austrians, commanded by Archduke Charles.
In order, the battles are

Abensberg,
Eckmuhl,
Aspern-Essling and
Wagram.


Each scenario has a map, full OB and any special rules. Typical dispositions, from the games played here, are also used to illustrate the scenarios.

—description from publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Fighting the Russians Before Russia 1805–1807: Austerlitz, Eylau and Friedland
description:
A Companion to In the Grandest Manner Compatible with any Napoleonic rules system.

This publication is the second accompaniment to the planned series of Companions to both support and supplement the rules, In The Grandest Manner, with themed scenarios that are developed and played at “The Situation Room”.

To make use of this latest accompaniment to the Companion series, you do not require any specific set of rules, although they are written with the rules mentioned above in mind.

As with the previous Companion, time is spent on exploring the intricacies of the rules which the Companions support. In this edition, the focus is the section within the rules that governs “Orders” and “Command & Control”. The next aspect of the rules to receive in depth analysis is the rules pertaining to Skirmishers and how they are used in the battles using In The Grandest Manner.

The scenarios, themselves, are based on four main battles that involved the Russians prior to 1812.
The battles covered are

Austerlitz,
Eylau and
Friedland.


Austerlitz is somewhat unusual, it was split into two separate battles because of its overall size, the northern and southern fronts. Each scenario has a map, full OB and any special rules. Typical dispositions, from the games played here, are also used to illustrate the scenarios.

—description from publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Red Coats and War Hawks: Skirmish Rules for Gaming the War of 1812
description:
Red Coats and War Hawks is a historical miniature game that enables and encourages the reader to recreate various battles and skirmishes of the War of 1812, while using model soldiers on their own tabletop battlefield. This game has been set up as a skirmish game in which players are assigned a unit of figures under the command of an officer, NCO or hero. Each figure is given a random number of actions that they can perform in their turn while dealing with the fundamentals of warfare such as command, movement, effects of small arms fire and artillery and the role that morale plays when the stresses of battle commence.

Numerous examples are included throughout the rule set and several advanced rule sections are also included allowing players to tailor games to their own preferences when using the various scenarios included or when designing their own game scenarios.

Red Coats and War Hawks rule set also includes the following items to make this rule set a complete package as well as providing the reader with two excellent sources (Knuckleduster Miniatures and Galloping Major Wargames) for gathering their forces:

1 Complete Rule Set
1 Scenario Supplement with 15 War of 1812 Scenarios
Scenario 1: The Battle of Brownstown (August 5th, 1812)
Scenario 2: Skirmish at the Oakwoods (August 9th, 1812)
Scenario 3: The Ogdensburg Skirmish (October 3rd, 1812)
Scenario 4: The Convoy Raid (October 27th, 1812)
Scenario 5: Gun Emplacement at Red House (November 28th, 1812)
Scenario 6: The Bridge at Frenchman’s Creek (November 28th, 1812)
Scenario 7: First Battle of the River Raisin (January 18th, 1813)
Scenario 8: The Battle of Ogdensburg (February 22nd, 1813)
Scenario 9: Britain’s Allies (Spring 1813)
Scenario 10: Raid on Frenchtown (April 29th, 1813)
Scenario 11: Amphibious Assault (May 25th, 1813)
Scenario 12: Battle of Beaver Dams (June 24th, 1813)
Scenario 13: Battle of the Thames (October 5th, 1813)
Scenario 14: Battle of Longwoods (March 5th, 1814)
Scenario 15: Skirmish at Nanticoke Creek (November 13th, 1814)

1 Reproducible Detailed Game Summary Chart
2 Clear Artillery Templates (Reproducible)
6 Reproducible Figure Information Sheets
400 Figure Cards


—description from publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: カエサルは賽を投げない (Caesar Does Not Throw Dice)
description:
カエサルは賽を投げない (Caesar Does Not Throw Dice) is one of deztec's game that sources components from local discount stores, and each copy may have different pieces, or even a different size box.

The game uses 1 permanent marker, 4 colored cubes, 1 green army figure, a deck of cards, and a book of mazes. If you exhaust the book of mazes it comes with, you're encouraged to find any book of mazes and continue playing.

Using a hand of cards, the players are allotted a certain number of action points to use as movement through the maze. The game is a race to the finish line. The army figure is used as a measurement tool and is the unit of movement. Cards of value 10 or higher may be used to make "shortcuts" through the maze, and become obligatory to use.

The first player to the finish wins.

It should be noted that deztec does not fully scope out the rules to their games and it will be left to the players to fill in various details.
categories: Racing
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Race, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: 巨獣大進撃 (Kyojuu Daishingeki)
description:
巨獣大進撃 (Kyojuu Daishingeki) is one of deztec's game that sources components from local discount stores, and each copy may have different pieces, or even a different size box.

The game uses 6 permanent markers, 6 colored cubes, 1 animal figure, and a book of maps. If you exhaust the maps it comes with, you're encouraged to find any map and continue playing.

The players act as kaiju battling over the land depicted on the map. Players use their marker to trace their kaiju's movement, and can trace over any line on the map (e.g. highway, river, coordinate grid). Players may cross another player's line, but cannot move along the same section of line another player has.

When a player cannot legally move, they are eliminated. The last remaining player wins.

It should be noted that deztec does not fully scope out the rules to their games and it will be left to the players to fill in various details.
categories: Abstract Strategy
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Paper-and-Pencil, Player Elimination

name: Buckskins and Rangers: Skirmish Rules for Gaming the French Indian Wars
description:
Buckskins and Rangers is a historical miniature game that enables and encourages the reader to recreate various battles and skirmishes of the French Indian Wars, while using 28mm model soldiers on their own tabletop battlefield. This game has been set up as a skirmish game in which players are assigned a unit of figures under the command of an officer, NCO or hero. Each figure is given a random number of actions that they can perform in their turn while dealing with the fundamentals of warfare such as command, movement, effects of small arms fire and artillery and the role that morale plays when the stresses of battle commence. Numerous examples are included throughout the rule set and several advanced rule sections are also included allowing players to tailor games to their own preferences when using the various scenarios included or when designing their own game scenarios.
Buckskins and Rangers rule set also includes the following items to make this rule set a complete package as well as providing the reader with two excellent sources (Galloping Major Wargames and Acheson Creations) for gathering their some of their forces and providing excellent tabletop terrain:

1 Complete Rule Set
1 Scenario Supplement with 12 French Indian War Scenarios
Scenario 1: Raid on Pickawillany, 1752
Scenario 2: The Jumonville Glen Affair, 1754
Scenario 3: Battle of Fort Necessity, 1754
Scenario 4: Raid in the Ohio Region, 1755
Scenario 5: Battle of Monongahela, 1755
Scenario 6: Battle on Snowshoes, 1757
Scenario 7: The Long March From Fort William Henry, 1757
Scenario 8: The Attack on German Flatts, 1757
Scenario 9: The Battle of Bloody Creek, 1757
Scenario 10: The Raid on St. Francis, 1759
Scenario 11: The St. Francis Raid Pursuit, 1759
Scenario 12: The Battle of Signal Hill, 1762

1 Reproducible Detailed Game Summary Chart
2 Clear Artillery Templates (Reproducible)
3 Reproducible Figure Information Sheets
320 Coloured Figure Cards


—description from publisher
categories: American Indian Wars, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Hand to Toad
description:
In Hand to Toad, players guide their toad familiars through an uninhabitable swamp to collect the highest scoring collection of ingredients. Combining strategic movement and information gathering up to 4 witches take turns casting spells to pick up items in the swamp.

Play proceeds in rounds comprised of turns. Each round continues until each player has cast all their spells once. On your turn:


You must cast one of your available spells.
You may pay energy to use the abilities of your familiar indicated on their identity card.


At the end of a round you may use one of the abilities of your familiar for free. Then you receive five more energy tokens, refresh all your spells, and begin the next round. Once three rounds have been completed, the game ends and players total their scores. The player with the highest score wins.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game

name: Drei-Eck
description:
Each player has to get his four pawns from his starting spaces to the starting spaces of his opponent to win the game. Movement is 1 space per turn. Movement is only possible if 3 pawns are standing in a triangle. The moved pawn has to pass between the two other pawns (own or opponent) of the triangle.

—user summary
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: Esprit de Corps: Power & Glory – Fast Action Wargames Rules for 19th Century Warfare
description:
Esprit de Corps – Power and Glory is designed to meet the challenge of bringing to life this exiting period of history in the form of fast-moving, exhilarating and true to life games of skill on the table-top, redolent with all the atmosphere, colour and heroism of the battlefields of the times.

Users of Esprit de Corps and Esprit de Corps A House Divided will be familiar with the general format and content of this rule book and with the rule mechanisms employed. Indeed there is some overlap in the period covered with that covered by Esprit de Corps, and complete overlap with A House Divided which is specifically honed to bring out the historical nuances and characteristics of the American Civil War. That is deliberate and in the latter case unavoidable given the broader canvas which Power and Glory seeks to address. For battles in the Crimea or the Indian Mutiny, for example, you have the choice to use either Esprit de Corps or Power and Glory for your wargames, the outcome will be more or less the same. Later in our period casualty rates increased with the widespread introduction of efficient breech-loading firearms and artillery and more effective machine-guns, and there was a resulting tendency to employ a somewhat more dispersed deployment of troops in the line of battle, all of which are accurately taken into account in these rules. Of course the development of Power and Glory' has benefited enormously from the experience of the authors with the two previous publications in the Esprit de Corps series and with rule books in the parallel Warlord series covering warfare in earlier periods of history.

Command and control and rapid manoeuvre are at the heart of these rules, just as they are in others in the Esprit de Corps and Warlord series. Though the effect of firepower is awesome, you cannot merely rely on defensive tactics alone for success. So be bold, exploit your chain of command to best advantage, concentrate your troops where it matters most, be aggressive where you can but defend resolutely where you must, and make best use of ground at all times. You can have great fun with these rules and your games will be fast and furious.

Authentic historical accuracy brings to life the character and atmosphere of combat in the wars of the second half of the 19th Century.
Fast action games at every level in all theatres of war.
Detailed and carefully calibrated troop classification accurately reproducing the characteristics of the units and
soldiers in each and every war world-wide.
Comprehensive coverage of combat formations and weaponry.
Figures based in standard multiples as elements - no need to re-base your troops.
Summary Starter Rules to get you into action fast.
Fully detailed and comprehensive explanation in the Main Rules.
Many worked examples of how the rules operate plus numerous explanatory diagrams.
Complete example battle account - 'Action at El Teb'.
Carefully crafted and entirely internally consistent for speedy action and exciting games.
Essentially simple D6 based rules systems common with others in the Esprit de Corps Series - play one play them all!
Alternate movement facilitates fast play.
Command & control - recreating the difficulties and frustrations of command on the battlefield with a fully functioning chain of command from the C-in-C to the unit CO.
Example army lists and guidelines on how to put together your miniature armies.
Bolt on, fully compatible additional rules in a separate Appendix taking you on into the early 20th Century.
Fast and easy access to all aspects of the rules - cross referenced and indexed throughout.
Playsheets included for hassle-free, rapid manoeuvre and swift combat resolution on the tabletop.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Esprit de Corps: A House Divided – Fast Action Wargames Rules for the American Civil War
description:
Esprit de Corps: A House Divided gives you the authentic challenge and drama of battle in the Civil War between the States.


Fast action games at every level - brigade, division, corps or multi-corps
Figures based in multiples as elements - no need to re-base your troops
Summary Starter Rules - get fighting fast
Full explanation in detailed Main Rules
Numerous worked examples of how the rules work - abundant explanatory diagrams too
Complete example battle account - Kernstown 1862 re-fought
Ready access - cross referenced and indexed throughout
Essentially simple D6 based rules systems - common with others in the Esprit de Corps Series - play one play them all
Alternate movement - facilitates play
Fully functioning chain of command from the C-in-C to unit CO
Command & control - recreates the difficulties and frustrations of command on the ACW battlefield
Comprehensive coverage of combat formations and weaponry
Detailed and carefully calibrated troop classification - accurately recreate the characteristics of the units and soldiers at each stage in the War
Generic army lists and guidelines on how to create your miniature armies
Authentic historical accuracy - the unique character of the American Civil War recreated


Detailed Army Lists and Scenarios to follow.

These rules, like those already published (Esprit de Corps for the period 1790 to 1860), have been carefully designed to incorporate a sophisticated series of integrated checks and balances to give a really good game and complete historical authenticity. Command and control and rapid manoeuvre are right at the centre of things. As a result there's quite a lot to get to grips with in this rulebook, but don't worry, the rule systems and mechanisms are basically simple and quick to use.

The rules are all about command and control, the absolute core of the Esprit de Corps system. You have to prompt your troops into action and at times restrain them from recklessly forgetting their orders. It enables the opposing sides to move alternately while retaining the potential for each to outmanoeuvre the other and for tactical surprise on the battlefield. As the action develops you will find more and more demands falling on your generals, drawing on their reserves of command and control. If the latter run out, your army will rapidly disintegrate and suffer defeat. Movement is rapid, each move representing from 10 to 15 minutes of action on the battlefield, and though ranges are significant, there is still plenty of scope for the use of manoeuvre to outplay your opponent, especially if your terrain is thoughtfully designed to accurately recreate that in the real theatre of operations you are depicting.

The systems for shooting, monitoring morale and determining the outcomes of attacks, melees and pursuits are simple, internally consistent and robust, so that they quick to resolve yet give an outcome which is appropriate and sensitive to the tactical situation, and, importantly, historically authentic. Normal (D6) dice are used for all transactions involving a random element (a die roll) throughout the rules.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: The Last Stand: Operation Berlin 1945
description:
The Last Stand is an operational game on the fighting between the Oder River and Berlin in the last months of the war in Europe. There is a campaign game beginning in February, a scenario beginning in April, and a short scenario covering just the end of the campaign.

The map consists of five 11"x17" sections and there are 632 uncut counters. The scale is 2-3 miles per hex and 3-5 days per turn.

The sequence of play has the Germans moving before combat but the Soviets moving after combat, which is intended to reflect the more rigid Soviet doctrine. Soviet artillery is more effective than German, with only German units being disrupted by barrages. Morale is important. Also important to the German side is communications; units that are not in communication with their HQ cannot move.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: Last Battles of the Reich
description:
This is a set of games on four of the last German offensive operations in World War II:


Operation Spring Awakening



Operation Solstice



Operation Nordwind



Operation Defend Berlin: this covers an move north from the Frnakfurt Bridgehead to delay the Soviet forces assembling for their Berlin offensive. The Germans have a limited supply of fuel points they must use whenever they move. Units are rated for "rearguard strength;" when a unit retreats this determines how far the attackers may advance.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: War in the Arctic
description:
War in the Arctic is about the German attempt (with Finnish assistance) to capture Murmansk in 1941.

The game contains five 11"x17" sheets and two 8.5"x11" sheets which must be assembled to form the map, approximately 250 uncut counters, rules, and a few pages of supplementary material such as historical commentary.

The map scale is about 1.25 miles per hex and turns are three days. Most units are companies, however generally a battalion moves as a single stack, with the companies basically used for step reduction.

The turn sequence is somewhat unusual in that after the Germans move and attack, there is a second German move, a Soviet move, and a Soviet attack, but the order these occur in is determined by a die roll.

Supply is important and the Germans have to move supply units to the front to engage in combat in addition to generally keeping units in supply. They can use pioneers to build minor roads to extend their supply capabilities.

German reinforcements are subject to some die-rolling to determine where the corps commanders are and what they do.

There is an eight-turn scenario and a 27-turn campaign game.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: Crossfire: Operation Sinyavino 1942
description:
Crossfire is about the Soviet attempt to break the siege of Leningrad in the latter half of 1942. It was unsuccessful but delayed the Germans enough for the Soviets to launch Operation Spark.

The game comes with a color map depicting both the Mga and Sinyavino fronts and the area between them. There are 355 uncut counters.

One unusual feature of the system is the turn sequence. The Soviets move, attack, and then move reserve units, after which the Germans move reserve units, the Soviets attack again, and then the Germans move non-reserve units and attack. Units are designated reserve or not at the start of each player's normal movement phase.

Another unusual feature is the movement system; German units have normal movement allowances but Soviet units do not. On the first turn of the game the Soviet player has movement points to distribute, but after that each unit's movement allowance is determined by the combination of a die roll and its distance from its HQ.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: A Motion to Sever
description:
A Motion to Sever covers Operation Lüttich, a German offensive near Mortain in August 1944.

The 21"x17" map is made from two sections and has a scale of one mile per hex. There are 244 uncut counters. Units are mostly battalions. Turns are twelve hours.

Turns follow a sequence of twelve phases including American air attacks, German artillery barrages, standard movement and combat, exploitation, and camouflage. In the latter phase German stacks can attempt to camouflage themselves under certain conditions, which helps protect them from air attacks. Camouflaged units move more slowly and cannot attack.

The combat system is quite complex with many different types of modifiers and column shifts (terrain, combined arms, different armor types, etc.) and a wide range of possible effects.

There is a nine-turn campaign game and several shorter scenarios.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: Stalingrad Corridor
description:
Stalingrad Corridor covers the German efforts to relieve the Stalingrad Pocket in 1942. This is a relatively small game with fewer than 200 counters.

There are four different movement type designations for units: wheel, track, horse, and leg. The German leg units must be rolled for every turn to see if they get a second movement phase.

The German player has several early-game options.
categories: Wargame, World War II

name: Panzer Grenadier Deluxe: Tactical World War II Rules
description:
Take command of your Battlegroup and recreate the decisive actions of WW2!

Now you too can order German Panzers to overrun Russian defences in Russia, lead a British Infantry attack at El Alamein or command US Paratroopers as they desperately hold their drop zones in Normandy!

PanzerGrenadier WW2 rules cover company to battalion sized actions, (where players field sections and platoons as their tactical units), providing straight forward yet comprehensive rules for WW2 tactical combat.

The rules are easy to learn with quick combat mechanisms. The central theme of the rules is command and control. This emphasis on command requires players to plan ahead, use period tactics such as combined arms to overcome the enemy and genuinely think about the command challenges before them!

Designed for 15-20mm but compatible with other scales.

The Deluxe Edition has less detail than the 2nd Edition with slicker mechanisms that create a fluid, higher tempo game with rules that still provide "realistic" wargame outcomes. The desire has been to rework the rules avoiding continual reference to charts, providing a game that is fast paced, easy to learn and with a minimum of record keeping.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Americans at War!: Saratoga, Vietnam, Grenada
description:
Americans at War! is a set of three games sold as a unit:


The Crushing Blow: The Saratoga Campaign of 1777. This has a main map running from Fort Crown to Albany and a smaller inset map for the area around St. Leger. There are 126 counters including 88 units. The British have to spend supply points to attack and have to stay in range of their supply depots, which move slowly. Morale is important, with an overall level for each side which is reduced by casualties; units rolling under the morale level must retreat.



The Battle for Tay Ninh. This seems to be a re-implementation of War Zone C: The Summer Offensive 1968.



Urgent Fury 1983 is about the invasion of Grenada. The map shows Grenada ans surrounding smaller islands. The American goal is to find documents, weapons caches, and people without taking too many casualties.
categories: American Revolutionary War, Modern Warfare, Vietnam War, Wargame

name: Larvapocalypse
description:
Larvapocalypse is a battle game for two or more players in which Monsters and Larva compete for survival. Each player controls a team of one defenseless Larva and one fighting Monster. Players take turns rolling dice and attempting to use their Monster to kill each others’ Larva, while trying to keep their own Larva from being killed. The last player with a surviving Larva is declared the winner.

The game is played with collectible 1”-1.5” figures released by Dead Bird Toys.
categories: Collectible Components, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Map Deformation, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid, Take That, Variable Set-up

name: The Game of Mentor, Ohio
description:
The object of the game is to bankrupt the competition by buying, selling, expanding, and investing in local business properties in Mentor, Ohio.

The play is similar to Monopoly in that players take turn rolling dice to move around the board, encountering spaces, and either purchasing an unowned business, paying a fee to another player if the business is owned, paying taxes at City Hall, and so on.

Players may lose by going bankrupt. The winner is the person with the most money when everyone decides to stop playing.

This game was produced as a fund-raiser.

—user summary
categories: Economic

name: 3rd Generation Warfare: 6mm rules
description:
Rules for larger battles at battalion level scale in 6mm.

The game is the same with a few minor differences.
Rather than activating a single squad or vehicle, an entire platoon is activated.
For the ground scale, cm are substituted to inches.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Battles for the West 1940-1945: World War II Scenarios – Volume I
description:
Battles for the West presents eleven historical scenarios for use with Battlegroup Panzer-Grenadier wargames rules, (though, of course, they can be used for any similar rules system). Each scenario provides players with objectives, orders of battle, deployment and terrain maps. The scenarios cover the main periods of fighting in the west, ranging from the campaign for France in 1940 to the Normandy campaign and its aftermath in 1944, through to the German Ardennes offensive in late 1944 and in Alsace in early 1945. The scenarios cover a variety of mid-sized actions using both infantry and armour.
(The battles of Operation Market Garden are not covered here as it is hoped they will be the subjects of a dedicated volume.)

ADVANCED RULES for Battlegroup Panzer-Grenadier are also included and cover Combined Assault Combat Groups, plus Off Board Artillery Rules taking into account national differences, pre-registered and prominent targets, miss deviations distances and Naval Gunfire support. In addition the Advanced Rules take account of Snipers whilst expanding the rules on AFV Hull Down Positions, Turretless AFV's, the KV2 and King Tiger, the Bogged Down Test, along with additional AT factors for exceptional gun types.

Finally the AMENDMENTS to existing rules, introducing Tank Group Commander, more information of AT weapons and inherent AT weapons plus revised factors, along with expanded Dead Ground rules and additional and revised points costs.

Scenarios:

YVOIR, BELGIUM, 1940
LISLET, FRANCE 1940
ARRAS, FRANCE 1940
VILLERS BOCAGE, NORMANDY 1944
RAURAY, NORMANDY 1944
HILL 112, NORMANDY 1944
MAIRY, LOIRE, 1944
STAVELOT, ARDENNES 1944
STOUMONT, ARDENNES 1944
OPERATION NORDWIND, ALSACE 1945
ACTION AT CINTHEAUX, NORMANDY 1944
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Battles for the East 1939-1945: World War II Scenarios – Volume II
description:
Battles for the East presents twelve further historical scenarios for use with Battlegroup Panzer-Grenadier wargames rules or any WWII rule system. Each scenario provides players with objectives, orders of battle, deployment and terrain maps. The scenarios cover the main periods of fighting in the east, ranging from the campaign for Poland in 1939, Operation Barbarossa through to Kharkov, Stalingrad, Kursk and the final Russian drive on Germany.

The scenarios cover a variety of mid-sized actions using both infantry and armour, but also include larger actions such as Targul Frumos.

Also included are the latest advanced rules & amendments.

Scenarios:

LODZ, POLAND 1939
HONKANIEMI, FINLAND, 1940
THE BRODY TRIANGLE, RUSSIA 1941
RASYENYA, RUSSIA 1941
MTSENSK, RUSSIA 1941
OLENINO, RUSSIA 1942
STALINGRAD, RUSSIA 1942
KHARKOV, RUSSIA 1943
KURSK, RUSSIA 1943
TARGUL FRUMOS, ROMANIA, 1944
OGLEDOW, POLAND, 1944
BERLIN, GERMANY, 1945


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Battles for the Mediterranean 1940-1944: World War II Scenarios – Volume III
description:
Battles for the Mediterranean presents ten further historical scenarios for Battlegroup Panzer-Grenadier WW2 wargame rules, (or, indeed, any similar wargame rule set). Each scenario provides players with objectives, orders of battle, deployment and terrain maps. The scenarios cover the main periods of fighting in the lands bordering the Mediterranean including Crete, the Western Desert, Tunisia, Sicily and Italy.

The scenarios cover a variety of actions using both infantry and armour.

(All scenarios are specific to 2nd Edition of Battlegroup PanzerGrenadier rules but are still useable with 1st Edition.)

Scenarios:

PINK HILL - CRETE
OPERATION COMPASS – WESTERN DESERT
OPERATION BATTLE AXE – WESTERN DESERT
ALAMEIN – THE SNIPE – WESTERN DESERT
HUNTS GAP - SIDI NSIR - TUNISIA
OPERATION TORCH – TUNISIA
BIAZZO RIDGE - SICILY
THE FACTORY – ANZIO - ITALY
THE RAILWAY STATION - MONTE CASSINO - ITALY
ROCHETTA - ITALY


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Wake up!
description:
Members of the an evil cabal and the human resistance are vying for the fate of the world. In order to summon a world-eating demon, an evil cult known as “The Cabal” is unleashing countless plagues on unsuspecting humanity. Fortunately, there is an underground "Resistance" that is fighting for the people on the surface. While they deal with various disasters, their Messenger will use his power to awaken and unite all of humanity.

In this asymmetrical intimidation and worker-placement game, 4 players will battle for the fate of humanity. 1 player will take the role of the dark hand of the Cabal- guiding a number of natural disasters against the Earth. 1-3 players will form "The Resistance" and dispatch a number of their members to deal with these disasters while attempt to awaken humanity. Over the course of 5 rounds, the Cabal player will choose disaster cards that the Resistance players must take down together by properly assigning their resources. However, the Resistance players' true goal is to awaken all 9 representatives of humanity. The Cabal player can distract them by creating disasters, hiding their costs and reducing their resources.

Are you ready to gamble for the fate of humanity?
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction

name: Alien Attack Expansion: Alien Reinforcements
description:
With Alien Attack's Alien Reinforcements, the Alien invading forces get much-needed support from the renowned Geezor, a no-nonsense Alien commander who has a familiar knowledge of the flesh bags.

Accompanying him are his elite Alien forces and another spaceship.

You will get everything needed in this supplement to play the Alien reinforcements in Alien Attack!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of Florida
description:
Slam Wars is a card battle game that celebrates the various wrestling territories that existed from the 1940's until the 1990's. It captures the unique flavor of the territory by using historical wrestlers, tag teams, managers, promoters, announcers and referees. Each Slam Wars set is a standalone game, but can be seamlessly integrated with any other Slam Wars set to form a larger playing pool.

Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of Florida comes in a 2-piece full-color dual deck poker box and includes a 20-page full-color instruction guide. There are a total of 90 playing cards:

44 solo wrestlers
16 tag teams
13 stat boosters
10 common match stipulations
6 special grudge match stipulations
1 championship


A round of play is called an "event" and consists of 7 matches (4 solo and 3 tag team). Seven match stipulation cards will be exposed, one for each match of the event. Each wrestler and tag team card is rated in 5 different categories (represented by symbols that match the stipulation cards). The objective is to strategically place the cards you were dealt in matches where they can perform the best (i.e. have high ratings). Like a good wrestling booker, you are trying to maximize your wrestler's strengths and minimize their weaknesses. After comparing the stats in that particular category, the card with the higher rating wins the match-up. Whichever player wins a majority of the 7 matches wins the event and is awarded the championship card. The holder of the championship card has an advantage heading into the next round of play. Much like poker, the rounds can continue until the participants decide to end it.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game

name: Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of Georgia
description:

It captures the unique flavor of the territory by using historical wrestlers, tag teams, managers, promoters, announcers and referees. categories: Card Game

name: Black Eagles: Rules for European Land Battles in the Seven Years War 1756-1763
description: Black Eagles are Miniature Wargame Rules designed for European Land Battles during the Seven Years War 1756-1763.
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Anton Glupsch entdeckt Garmisch-Partenkirchen
description:
The board is a very colorful map of Garmisch Partenkirchen and surrounding areas. There are locations on the map where a card an be picked up. There are several kinds of cards; hiking cards, site attraction cards, and happy yodeler cards. The cards give information about local interest points and also have certain tasks the player must complete either by rolling the die or moving to other locations on the board. Players try to collect the most of the different types of cards and get to the top of the Zugspitze.

—user summary
categories: Travel

name: Blobbiemundo: Despertar de las Gárgolas – Volumen I
description:
Introduces 8 new Limestone Statue shapes.
In their natural state, these statues are Objects with a Defense of 20 points in all 3 environments, but no other abilities.
These statues have Apotropaic powers of transformation into Gargoyles: flying mammals with many abilities.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game

name: Les Gens Braves: Rules for Wargaming the Franco-Prussian War
description:
Les Gens Braves are Miniature Wargame Rules for the Franco-Prussian War in 15 or 25mm.

The rules cover weather, command and control, movement, charge, French counter-attacks, firing, Chassepot & mitrailleuses, melee, morale, disorganisation...

Comes with background, information and tactics on both armies.

—user summary
categories: Book, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: The Long Endure: American Civil Wargaming
description:
Miniature Wargame rules for simulating the American Civil War.

43 page book + 4 page card playsheet.
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Game of Triads or Chords
description:
This card game from 1898 by music publisher Theodore Presser was intended to be an educational aid to music students.

The deck consists of 39 cards, which together form the basic chords possible for each of the 13 keys. Each card has a large letter in the middle, representing its note. The key to which that note belongs is in the upper right corner, and the musical symbol for that key (sharps or flats) is in the upper left. The bottom of the card lists all three notes in that key.

The rules say that the game can be played as a simple set collection game like Authors, but is more interesting with a second set of rules, which it says resemble "Cassino".

Each player is dealt a hand of five cards, and five more are dealt face up on the table. In turn, each player must if possible place a card from hand onto the table that matches the key of one of those showing. If unable to place a matching card, he may place any other card on the table. The player who puts the final card in a triad or chord collects all three as a set.

If no cards remain on the table, the next player puts down any card to start the process over. When any player runs out of cards, one more card is dealt to each player. Once all cards have been played, the player collecting the largest number of sets wins.

—user summary
categories: Music

name: Maggi's Fliegerspiel
description:
This is a colorful roll-and-move game published during the 1930s by Swiss food company Maggi that specialized in bouillon cubes and sauces. Players start from Maggi's pre-WWII factory in Kempttal, and fly an open cockpit, single-seat plane across Europe, around Africa, over to Australia and then home via India, the Middle East and Russia.

The illustrations are highly racist by today's standards. The Maggi representative is shown receiving a nose ring in return for offering Maggi soup to a pair of natives southern Africa, escaping from a dagger-wielding Arab by making soup with a bouillon cube, and being tied to a tree by Australian Aborigines while they feast on his Maggi cargo.

—user summary
categories: Adventure, Aviation / Flight, Travel

name: Hyakuninisshu English Translated Karuta 51-100: Part 2
description:
Finally you can play like Chihayafuru!

This English Hyakuninisshu Karuta (poetry card game) uses the original Japanese poems from Ogura Hyakuninisshu translated to English "wakas" (5+7+5; 7+7 syllables). This karuta includes card no. 51-100 (Part 2).

All cards have both the Japanese original poem with a unique illustration or text, from the original karuta from Shogundo plus the English translation (by Clay MacCauley 1917) on the back of the cards.

Review from Japan Center Michigan State University 2020-03-09
“…really appreciated how you used the 5-7-5-7-7 syllable translations, and the reading app made it feel just as real to them as the “traditional” version of the game.”

Tip: Download the free iOS audio reader app (companion app for this game). You can use the reader app for practicing and also when you are only two persons and you need a reader. We have two reader apps. 1. Hyakuninisshu EN : This reader app sings the poems exactly like the Japanese wakas (original poems)which are sung since 400 years. 2. Read Hyakunin Isshu EN: This reader app is read normally. It is easier to understand when it is read normally but the app which is sung sounds more genuine like the original Japanese karuta.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting

name: Ogoola Karuta:  51-100 English Modern
description:
The Ogoola Karuta Poetry Game ENGLISH MODERN (cards 51-100)

Play like Chihayafuru with poems written in English!

This edition uses 50 modern English poems from the 19th century until today. Some of the poets included are Tennyson, Whitman, Yeats, Joyce, Plath, Pound, Frost, Eliot, Heaney and Merwin. Contains 50 reading cards, 50 playing cards and a poetry book (instructions, rules, history and the 100 poetry quotes both classic and modern).

Karuta is a game about listening and finding FAST what you are listening to in the cards you will pick. Grab the correct cards FAST before the others do in order to win! Known as an intellectual martial arts game in Japan. The cards have famous poetry quotes on them but no prior knowledge is needed!

This edition is not a translation of the original Japanese Hyakuninisshu poems. However,the original Japanese cards from Shogundo are printed on the backside as a design so you can play the game in Japanese if you can read and understand it.

Tip: Download the reader app available on Google Play and the App Store.
Enjoy to the reader Myrra Malmberg. This app serves as the reader when you want to practice or when everybody wants to play. Especially if you are only two persons, this app will allow both persons to play the game. The iOS app is free.

iOS app: Ogoola Karuta EN 100
Android: Karuta English Ogoola
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Memory, Wargame, Word Game
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Take That

name: Limbo Road
description:
It has been written that “The road to hell is paved with good intentions.” However, that road to hell (or heaven) first leads to limbo. In this game you and a friend are full of good intentions, and abstractly perform good deeds – both big and small – throughout your lives. Some turn out poorly, however, so you will have to travel the limbo road. At the end of the journey, only one of you can win the game and move on.

Both players will use cards to move along Limbo Road, along with a few special cards to help their cause or hinder their opponent. They'll collect colored Good Deed tiles which may provide victory points, and Fate tiles which will provide special actions. Upon reaching limbo the game becomes a bit restricted and players will have to choose their actions more carefully.... This is an easy-playing game with some interesting decisions and, hopefully, decent levels of excitement and fun.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Deduction, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Variable Set-up

name: Larvapocalypse: Series 1 Expansion
description:
Larvapocalypse: Series 1 Expansion contains an additional 25 Larvapocalypse figures to the game.

Series 1 figures were released in booster packs of 5 and 10, the 5 pack containing an additional board piece.
categories: Collectible Components, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Map Deformation, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid, Take That, Variable Set-up

name: Fingerlings Ruckus Card Game
description:
This is a simplified reskin of Ruckus (similar to the L.O.L. Surprise version). Players collect cards with pictures of Fingerlings (brightly colored monkey characters) by stealing from other players to form sets. There are 72 cards (6 cards for each of 12 characters).

The endgame rules differ slightly from traditional Ruckus. Instead of shouting "OUT!" as in traditional Ruckus, players shout "FINGERLINGS!"

The game comes with a toy Fingerling that is not used in the game. Different boxes will have different colors of Fingerlings (visible through the packaging).
categories: Card Game, Children's Game

name: The Little Prince: Story Board Adventure
description:
NOTE: Physical Game Coming Soon
Additional Note: The Original PnP is a prototype of the new game coming out. If you have it, please do not distribute it.

You are on an adventure to trace The Little Prince’s journey through space. You come across different destinations such as planets with strange inhabitants, beautiful creatures, and dangerous baobabs!

Players will travel to different destinations on the game board trying to obtain cards corresponding to those destinations on the game board. A Destination is a place on the board where the illustration from the book “The Little Prince” is present and where a player may land. Specific actions are carried out when a player lands on these places.

The places where a player may land between each destination are the gray and red star spaces. When a player lands on these spaces, different actions may be carried out, such as drawing cards from the decks and exchanging cards from the discard pile. The first player to have three of the same destination cards, revealing it, and passing/landing on the destination that corresponds to the cards wins the game.

So, if a Player collects three “Asteroid B-612" cards, they must reveal it from their "secret" hand and then proceed to pass/land on the destination “Asteroid B-612” to win the game.
categories: Children's Game, Print & Play

name: Cross 6
description:
There are lines with numbers in white spaces.

At the end of each line, there is a number in a grey space.

For each line, the sum the numbers in white spaces must be equal to the grey number.

To win, you will have to cross exactly 6 white spaces. Each crossed white space won’t count for the grey numbers value.

Take a pen and a timer (10 minutes for a 1-player game, 5 for a 2-player game). When you are ready to start, launch the timer.

If you finish the game before the end of the timer, you win. If you have lost, look to one of the solutions.

—description from the designer
categories: Deduction, Print & Play, Puzzle

name: Invazions: Philibert
description:
Philibert is a real board game store in Strasbourg, France.

One more place for the Invazions game.

This place can replace one of the places in the base game. It has a defense of 5, and the following effects:

Humans: as long as there is a search on the place, your card hand is increased by 1
Zombies: +1 zombie
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Heist: The Game of Chaos
description:
Heist is a fast-paced, collaborative party game that pits two teams of crooks against each other in a bank robbery gone mad. Gameplay is fueled by chaos and player interaction. There are no turns, just non-stop action.

Two crews will race to resolve tasks, remove targets and complete challenging mini-games by using tool cards and performing absurd actions. To win you'll need to stay on your toes and keep an eye out for your teammates. Who knows what will happen…? Why are those thugs after Gayle? Who turned off the lights? Where did this drink come from? Why’s Tommy sleepin’ on the job?

Win or lose, Heist is a blast to play — the bee's knees if you will. So roll up your sleeves, pour yourself a stiff one and get ready for the Heist of the century.

—description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Humor, Mafia, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Blood & Guts: U.S. Army Guide for Disposable Heroes II
description:
Blood & Guts is the U.S. Army Supplement for Disposable Heroes II

This book contains all the platoon lists for the U.S. Army. It also contains the weapons, vehicles, and support weapons used by the U.S. Army in WWII.

The three scenarios allow players to put their U.S. forces up against the Germans in two theaters (Italy and Normandy) covering three different types of tactical challenges (Defense, Attack, and Airborne Drop).

A short history and timeline of the U.S. involvement in WWII and some ends notes on how to use the book gives players the complete Disposable Heroes II supplement they need to play the U.S. Army in WWII.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Angriff! German Army Book for Disposable Heroes II
description:
Angriff, the German Army Book, has been updated and expanded (128 pages) to be used with the Disposable Heroes II Wargaming Rules by the author Keith Stine.

The book contains all the platoon lists for the Wehrmacht (including Heer, SS, and Luftwaffe ground units.) It also contains the weapons, vehicles and support weapons used by the German Army in WWII.

The three scenarios allow players to put their German forces up against their enemies in three theaters (France 1940, Soviet Union 1943, and Holland 1944), covering three types of tactical challenges (Defense, Attack and Armored Infantry Assault.)

A short history and the timeline of the German Army in WWII and some end notes on how to use the book gives players the complete Disposable Heroes II supplement they need to play the German Army in WWII.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Hackers \' Epoch
description:
Hackers \’ Epoch Cybersecurity Card Game is a tool for teaching students many of the terms associated with threats and vulnerabilities within the scope of Cybersecurity. It is a STEM.org Authenticated Educational Product.

These cards gamify some aspects of cybersecurity training and provide the educator with a
starting point for the discussion of cybersecurity principles with students.

As students play the game, they use the cards to build their own network infrastructure
and defend it, while attempting to Deceive, Disrupt, Deny, Degrade, or Destroy systems and services belonging to other players. The goal is to add as many systems as possible to one’s own infrastructure before the game ends.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Educational, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Fields of Battle: Without Fortune – Arnhem 1944
description:
Fields of Battle: Without Fortune, Arnhem 1944 is a WW2 Scenario Book for DHCSB

This is the 2nd installment in the scenario campaign series Fields of Battle. Without Fortune includes 20 platoon level/small unit skirmish scenarios, all centered in 1944 Arnhem and the British Paras.
Disposable Heroes is needed for referenced information in this Scenario Book.

Operation Market Garden devised by British Field Marshal Montgomery has been labeled as one of the most daring plans in the entirety of the Second World War. The plan called for use of some 34,600 Allied airborne infantry, the Market, to provide the blanket for armored forces, the Garden, to roll forward on as they advanced into Germany in what is known as the largest airborne battle in history. The First Allied Airborne Army under tactical command by General Browning was composed of British, American, and Polish troops who would be dropped ahead of the land based armored advance of British XXX Corps to secure key bridges along a route known as the Corridor through the Netherlands to the Rhine. General Brian Horrocks, the commander of XXX Corps likened the operation to threading a series of needles as each bridge is secured and passed with the last bridge being the most essential to it’s success. This last bridge was Arnhem and was tasked to the British 1st Airborne Division to hold for an estimated 48 hours till XXX Corps could link up with them. This was an operation that was more dependent on fortune than the men partaking it could imagine.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: A Corner of Hell Supplement: Platoon Organisations & Additional Rules for World War II Skirmish Gaming
description:
A Corner of Hell Supplement: Platoon Organisations & Additional Rules for World War II Skirmish Gaming

36 platoon organisations to the popular A Corner of Hell, the WW2 Skirmish miniature rules.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: By the Sword: Rules for Medieval & Renaissance Skirmish Gaming c400 to 1600AD
description: By the Sword are Miniature Wargame skirmish rules for the Medieval and Renaissance period 400 - 1600 for 25/28mm minis.
categories: Ancient, Book, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: War in El Dorado: Warfare in the New World c1492 to 1550 – A Campaign Supplement for By the Sword
description:
War in El Dorado

A set of skirmish rules to simulate warfare in the New World.
Supplement to By The Sword from the same author.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Renaissance, Wargame
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Empire of the Steppes: Fast Play Wargame Rules for the Era of the Great Mongol Conquests 1206-1299 AD
description:
Fast play wargame rules for the era of the great Mongol conquests, 1206-1299 AD.

Includes 31 army lists.
categories: Book, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Das Turnier oder Ritter-Spiel
description:
This is a dice-rolling gambling game published in Vienna in the early 1800s.

Around a central scene of knights jousting are 20 illustrated squares each with one of the possible combinations of two dice. The double six appears in the middle image. Most of the squares show pieces of a knight's equipment, while the rest have various animals or objects as well as a wizard (3-3).

The rules say that all players should start by putting 24 Marks into the pot(the middle of the board). Players take turns rolling and must follow the instructions for the space showing their die roll. These either allow the player to take that amount from the pot or pay that much into the pot.

The first player to roll a double six takes the whole pot and ends the game. If there is nothing left in the pot when a double six is rolled, all players have to throw in half the original bet, which goes to the winner.

—user summary
categories: Dice, Medieval

name: Day of Eagles: A Game of Aerial Combat in WW2
description: Day of Eagles is a set of simple Miniature Wargame Rules to simulate aerial combat in WW2.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Shenandoah: A Civil War Miniatures Campaign System – The Peninsular Module
description:
A Shenandoah American Civil war Miniatures Campaign System for the James river Campaign.

The Penisula Campaign Module if the first follow up to Shenandoah. The basic system is mostly unchanged. What this module offers is a new map and vehicle to give meaningful strategic reasons for your ACW miniatures battles..

Map system for running the campaign using any rules set.
categories: American Civil War, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Armies in Crisis: A Game of Combined Arms Combat in World War Two
description:
Armies in Crisis is a set of miniature wargame rules to simulate combined arms combat during WWII.

It is based on Contemptible Little Armies rules for WWI.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Phase Order
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: 'Floating Castles': Fast-Play Rules for Naval Warfare in the Ironclad Era, c. 1860-1885
description:
Floating Castles are miniature wargame rules to simulate naval warfare during the 1860-1885 period.

The rules cater for any scale with distances measured in yards and speed in knots, converted into inches or fractions.

You'll need D10's as the rules are based around percentage rolls for most outcomes.

The sequence of play is straightforward and is based on alternate moves, with each player moving one ship at a time based on an initiative roll. Shooting is simultaneous but torpedoes and ram attacks have their own placing in the sequence.

There are rules for weather and stability, with a die roll at the start of the game to determine the conditions of play.

Movement is measured in inches, with variable maneuverability depending upon the speed and size of ships involved.

Shooting is determined after movement has taken place. All shooting depends upon arcs of fire although, once again, there are no templates provided. If a target is in range and inside a firing arc at the end of the movement phase, it can be fired upon.

To hit a target, a D10 is rolled for each gun requiring a base 'to hit' score depending upon range. There are, in a addition, a small number of +1 modifiers for sea state, angle of fire etc.

If a hit is scored, a percentile roll is made to detemine damage, with various hit locations and effects. Armour penetration is dealt with by averaging out the actual armour protection of a target across the whole ship, with each vessel classified as either light, medium, heavy or super heavy. Armour penetration depends upon a D10 roll based on the weapon fired and the strength of the armour, modified by range.

There are additional straightforward rules for spar, locomotive and towed torpeodoes, mines, ramming and boarding. These are dealt with after the movement and shooting phases have been resolved.

At the end of the rulebook there are 13 comprehensive page of data tables for virtually every fleet that you might wish to deploy, with stats for both minor nations and the major powers. There are also details of the formulae used to calculate the stats for each ship, so you can always fill in the blanks for those vessels that aren't listed.
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Nautical, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Huns in the Sun: A Game of Aerial Combat in World War I, 1915 to 1918
description: Huns in the Sun are miniature wargame rules to simulate aerial combat in the First World War.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War I
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Cold War Hotshots: A Game of Aerial Combat in the Jet Age, c. 1950-1967
description: Cold War Hotshots is an attempt to produce a fast and enjoyable game of aerial combat which can be played out on an ordinary tabletop. This set covers both real and hypothectical conflicts set in the period between the outbreak of the Korean War and the Six Day War in the Middle East.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Korean War, Miniatures, Vietnam War, Wargame
publishers: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)

name: Cercado por Mortos
description: Surrounded by the Dead (Cercado por Mortos) is a game-book - a book in which you are the main character, making decisions that can lead to a happy ending or major failures. A pencil, paper and a 6-sided die is all you need to venture into a world that is both realistic and fantastic - as if a zombie epidemic were to occur the next night, as if the first zombies were the animated bodies of your neighbors next to…
categories: Book, Zombies

name: Clash of Sabres: Tabletop Wargaming Rules for Aerial Combat 1948-1970
description:
Clash of Sabres

Miniature wargame rules simulating post WW2 aerial combat.

Written by two ex-pilots, explore dog fighting in the early jet-age.
Later piston aircraft are included too for some very interesting scenarios….
categories: Book, Korean War, Miniatures, Vietnam War, Wargame

name: East of Suez: Moderate Level Rules for Modern and Middle Eastern Wargaming (1950 to 1970)
description:
East of Suez

Designed for Post War to circa 1980.
These rules were primarily written to cover Britains’ retreat from Empire and the various Middle East Wars.'

Intended for skirmish level actions, a platoon of infantry and a tank troop plus supports will give a good game over an hour or two.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Tut-Tut or A Run in a Motor Car
description:
This is a British set collection card game. It has a deck of 48 cards, divided into sets of four cards, each naming a British city.

There also is a spinner built into the bottom of the box. Eight segments of the spinner indicate points gained between 0 and 60. The other four segments have losses of between 2 and 20. Printed on the bottom are a matching 12 segments, one per city in the deck.

To play, the deck is reduced to one set per player. The cards are then shuffled and dealt out evenly. Before play begins, the dealer without looking spins a dial fixed into the box and closes the lid.

Play then proceeds as in Pit. Players call out any number of cards they wish to exchange. They may not name or hint at cities they have or want. As soon as one player collects a set of four, he announces "Tut-Tut". The box is then opened to reveal how many points plus or minus that city is worth to the winner of this round.

Play continues until one player reaches a point total that varies by number of players, from 300 for four players to 100 for 11 to 12 players.

Each card bears the same photograph of four people in a car that resembles a 1905 Packard N. That and the mechanism suggests that it was published soon after Pit became a hit in the United States in 1903-04.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Travel

name: Game of Cities
description:
This is a question and answer card game about cities around the world. The deck includes 100 cards, and each card has 6 questions with that card's city as the answer. Each card also shows the date the city was founded and its population as of 1889. Former cities like Sparta, Troy and Pompeii have no population shown.

When used as an education aid, the teacher may draw cards, ask a question and award it to the player first able to answer correctly. Cards may also be distributed, with players taking turns asking a question: they either give it to the other player answering correctly, or keep it if no other player can answer. In either case, the player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

—user summary
categories: Educational, Trivia

name: Lobbyist: Shaping the Vote
description:
In the world of politics it seems nothing is every completely clear and many c operations work hard and spends millions to see that their interests are put before all others. In the game of Lobbyist - Shaping the Vote, players get to try their hand at lobbying, working to influence politicians to vote their desired way while competing with other lobbyist who are working towards a different means and outcome.

Lobbyist - Shaping the Vote is a game where players take on the role of Lobbyist trying to influence the political committee to voting in their desired way. Each player is a lobbyist starting with $50,000. The board is a political committee voting on five issues, Education, Health and Welfare, Infrastructure, Taxes and Revenue, Crime and Punishment. Each issue's influence is represented by a dice value and Lobbyist play cards from their hand to increase and decrease those dice values. Around the board will be 5,7,or 9 (depending on difficulty of play) unique politicians, all with a voting position value for each of the five issues. Politicians will not vote yes until the die values matches or exceeds their voting position values. Each lobbyist it working to gather desired votes on these issues, wanting to gather yes votes on two issues, and no votes on two issues, being indifferent on the fifth issue (each player lobbyist card has different yes/no goals on their cards).

Throughout the game players will have cards in hand and will draw and play a card on their turn. Most cards will allow then to influence one or more of the voting issue dice. Vote cards are shuffled into the deck and when one of these is drawn the player immediately plays the Vote card and the committee votes on the issues. Prior to voting though the Lobbyist all have one final chance to influence their politicians by either taking a vote action (indicted on the cards), or by spending up to $20,000 of their money to increase or decrease dice values. Once each player has had a chance to take or pass on an action, the politicians vote on the issues and players get yes/no vote tokens for their successful lobbying. Game ends after the fifth vote happens and final scores are tallied.

I came up with this game idea after sitting through a number of political action committee meetings and hearing the same info numerous times, so I started jotting ideas. The can has been play tested some and everyone I have played with has enjoyed the game at this point.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Negotiation, Political, Print & Play
mechanics: Bribery, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Take That, Voting

name: Once Upon a Time...In the West Country
description:
Once Upon a Time...In the West Country

Simple skirmish rules for the English Civil War (1640-1660). Troops are raw, trained, or veteran, and have a few skills (such as fire-combat experts, etc.). Cavalry, infantry, and artillery are catered for. Includes 2 scenarios.

There is no fixed time or ground scale. Designed for 1 figure = 1 man, using 25mm figures.

The rules suggest no more than 6 figures per player.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: English Civil War Sieges: Rules & Scenarios for Wargamers
description:
English Civil War Sieges
An extensive guide to running ECW siege scenarios, for any ECW miniatures system.

Covering all aspects of siege warfare, including - siege equipment (such as fire-pikes, petards, heated shot & siege engines), obstacles (such as faggots, gabions & gulay gorod) and the structure and design features used in fortifications, as well as the means employed by attackers to counter them.

5 siege specific scenarios:

The Attack on the South Gate, Gloucester 1643
Treachery at Windsor, 1642
The Storming of Chester, 1645/1646
The Storming of Bristol, 1643
Basing House, 1645


—description from the publisher

name: 悪霊退治 (Akuryō Taiji)
description:
The trick-taking game 悪霊退治 (Akuryō Taiji), roughly translated as "Demon Extermination", was released as part of the publisher ruri ruri games' (るりるりゲームズ) Autumn 2019 box of trick-taking games, titled トリテセット５ (Trick Taking Set 5).

It is a solo trick-taking game for one player against a "demon" character. The game consists of 1-9 in four suits and 9 "seal cards". The suit of the cards is shown on the back, and the first hand is played with only the green and yellow cards. The blue cards are added for the second hand, and the red cards are added for the next hand.

The player's goal is to seal a certain amount of the seal cards, which have conditions such as "three cards of the same value" or "two cards from each of two suits".

It is a "may follow" game, where the "demon" will play the top card from a stack of cards representing their hand, and the player will choose their card. If the player wins, the cards may be used to help satisfy a seal card. Depending upon the cards played by the "demon", special effects may be activated, such as causing the player to discard their highest ranked card.

Once a player has satisfied all face up seal cards, they win. If the game reaches a state where they cannot, they lose.
categories: Card Game
publishers: るりるりゲームズ (ruri ruri games)

name: Victory Decision: Raid!
description:
Victory Decision: Raid! is a new Ultraskirmish game that allows you to command a squad sized force in the momentous conflict of World War II. Each unit in Victory Decision: Raid! represents one individual infantry model.

Games are focused on infantry squad vs infantry squad, and typically have 6-10 figures per side. These rules cover almost all aspects of World War II wargaming, from Troop Quality and Leadership to Bunker Assaults, Combat in Buildings and Vehicle combat.

Victory Decision: Raid! features a unique Leadership-modified alternate unit activation system. The result is a fun and fast paced war game that involves both players constantly.

The rules are designed with 20-28mm miniatures in mind, but the Victory Decision: Raid! game system is flexible enough to handle any miniatures from 15mm to 32mm. So whatever your existing miniature collection consists of, you can start playing right away.

This rulebook not only provides Scenarios but also 27 Point based Force Lists for British, German, Soviet and US forces from early to late war.
All necessary Game Markers are also included within this book.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Victory Decision: Advanced Wargaming Rules – World War II: Airborne Assault Scenario
description:
This is a 4 page free scenario to compliment Fallschirmjaeger, British and US Paratrooper books.

Victory Decision: World War II is an action based game that allows you to command a platoon sized force or more in this momentous conflict. It features a unique Leadership-modified alternate unit activation system. The result is a fun and fast paced war game that involves both players almost constantly.

The rules cover virtually all aspects of World War II gaming. The full rulebook contains rules for:

Moving, Hiding, Infiltrating and Spotting,
Shooting and Concentrated Fire Actions,
Assault and Close Combat Actions,
Artillery and Air Strikes, Bunker Assaults, Night Fighting, Foxholes, Tank Pits and much more...


Victory Decision emphasises Troop Quality and Leadership and includes a fast and detailed Vehicle combat system.

The rules cover individually based infantry miniatures and also group- or multibased miniatures, aka Infantry Stands. While designed with 20-28mm miniatures in mind the Victory Decision game system is flexible enough to handle any miniatures from 6mm to 32mm. So whatever your existing miniature collection consists of, you can start playing right away.

This rulebook not only provides Scenarios but also Point based Army Lists for late war British, German, Soviet and US forces. All necessary Game Markers are also included within this book.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Victory Decision: Advanced Wargaming Rules – World War II: Chinese Army Guide
description:
The Army Guide supplements for Victory Decision: World War II miniatures game are comprehensive army lists.

A copy of the Victory Decision: World War II rulebook is necessary to fully use the content of this book.

The Chinese Army Guide is your comprehensive guide to using Chinese armies in Victory Decision: World War II.

The Chinese role and importance in World War II is often overlooked or misjudged by western wargamers and even historians. For China World War II has a rather different meaning then that in the rest of the world. Interestingly enough in China, no one talks about the Second World War; instead people talk about the Anti-Japanese War.

This book covers the Chinese forces of this War against the Imperial Japanese Army from 1937 to 1945;
be it Kuomintang forces (Chinese National Revolutionary Party) or Mao Tse-tung’s People Liberation Army.

Included are the following army lists and all the relevant HQ, Combat, Fast or Light Support Elements and Heavy Support Elements:

1937 – 1938 Nanking National Revolutionary Army
1937 – 1941 Soviet Advised National Revolutionary Army
1942 – 1943 National Revolutionary Army
1944 – 1945 Late War Chinese US equipped X and Y-Forces
1937 – 1945 Chinese Red Army Guerrilla Forces


—description from the publisher
